She works selling the fruits of the region, such as oranges, mandarins, papaya, bananas, chirimoya and cocona, both fruits indigenous to Peru, and other types of fruit.

With this loan of 1,000 soles (Peruvian currency), which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy fruit by the hundreds. With the capital she will continue buying little by little, to always have fresh fruit to sell during the 6 months in which she will be repaying her loan.

Elidia is 49 years old. She has worked tirelessly into the evening since she was 12, including tending to deliveries to her clients' homes. From her business she actively participates in the local Juvenile Patrol , working to fight delinquency in the area around the Plaza de Armas.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elidia es una mujer luchadora y socia del Banco Comunal “Corazones Valientes II” del Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo. Vive en la región San Martín, provincia de San Martín. El negocio está ubicado en Jr. Grau (esquina con Jr. Ramírez Hurtado y frente a la plaza de Armas). Se dedica a la venta de frutas regionales como naranjas, mandarinas, papaya, plátanos, chirimoya, cocona y otros.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará frutas en cientos y poco a poco con el capital que tiene seguirá comprando, porque sino se malogran las frutas durante los seis meses en el cual tendrá que pagar su crédito.

Elidia tiene 49 años, desde las 12 del día trabaja incansablemente hasta la noche, incluso atiende los pedidos a domicilio que le hacen sus clientes y también desde su negocio participa activamente el la Patrulla Juvenil del Cercado de Tarapoto resguardando de la delincuencia la zona de la Plaza.

loans.use: Purchase of fruit

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Elvina

texts.es:
Elvina is a member of the community bank "Los Jasmines", located in the province and district of Moyobamba in the San Martín region. She works selling a variety of cooked legumes from her sales stall in the wholesale food market in the city of Moyobamba.

With this loan of 2000 soles (Peruvian currency) which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy sacks of legumes, both those grown in the jungle region (local legumes such as fréjol huasca, chiclayo) and those produced in the coastal regions (including local legumes known as fréjol canaria and caballero, along with peas, large white lima beans, broad beans and lentils). This will allow her to offer variety to her clientele every day.

At 44, Elvina is a woman concerned about helping her children move ahead. She longs to market bread and cheeses fromn the city of Chachapoyas to complement her fruit sales.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elvina es socia del Banco Comunal “Los Jasmines”, ubicado en la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Se dedica a la venta de menestras cocinadas en sus diferente variedades, los mismos que ofrece en su puesto de ventas ubicado en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Moyabamba.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará menestras en sacos, tanto los que se producen en la región de la selva: fréjol huasca, chiclayo, como lo que se produce en la región de la costa y sierra: fréjol canario, caballero, alverjas, pallares, habas, lentejas y de esa manera ofrecer variedad diariamente a su basta clientela.

Elvira con sus 44 años es una mujer muy preocupada por sus hijos para sacarles adelante. Anhela comercializar panes y quesos de la ciudad de Chachapoyas para complementar su venta .

loans.use: Purchase of legumes (frijoles, lentils, peas, white lima beans, broad beans, etc.)

loans.name: Erica Consuelo

texts.es:
Erica Consuelo, member of the community bank Mujeres Emprendadoras (Enterprising Women), works selling groceries, bread and vegetables. She also sells salchipapas ( a popular fast food in Peru) and grilled meats in a bodega located in her own house in the Prolongación Manual del Águila 123 in the district and province of Moyabamba and the region of San Martín. When she separated from her husband she decided to apply her experience selling clothes to the launch of her own business, as a way to raise her 3 children and give them an education.

With this loan of 1,500 soles (Peruvian currency), which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a variety of groceries including 50 pound sacks of rice, sugar and various legumes, packages of toilet paper, boxes of canned fish and fruits, liters of oil, boxes of soap of different brands and bins of eggs. All of this will stock her store with a varied inventory to offer to her clients.

Erica always shows herself to be good-humored and willing to work hard to get ahead. She is 30 years old and has 2 children, both still small. She longs to convert her tiny bodega into a Minimarket.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Erica Consuelo, socia del Banco Comunal Mujeres Emprendedoras, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, panes, y verduras, también a la venta de salchipapas y parrillas en una bodega ubicada en su propia casa en la Prolongación Manuel del Águila Nº 123 , distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Con experiencia en la venta de ropas al separarse de su esposo decidió poner un negocio propio y así poder criar y dar educación a sus 3 hijos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará diversos abarrotes como sacos de 50 kilos de arroz, azúcar y menestras de diversos variedades, papel higiénico en paquetes, conservas de pescado y de frutas en cajas, aceite por litros, cajas de jabón de diferentes marcas, huevos en jabas y de esa manera tener surtido sus productos y ofrecerlo a su clientela.

La señora Erica se muestra siempre como una persona jovial y luchadora, tiene 30 años, 2 hijos aún pequeños y anhela convertir su bodega en un MiniMarket.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries (rice, sugar, legumes, canned goods)

loans.name: Julia Rosario

texts.es:
Julia Rosario belongs to a women leaders group and lives in La Banda D. Shilcayo in the San Martín region of Peru. She is dedicated to selling fresh fish wholesale at a local market. A loan will help Julia prepare herself for the upcoming season when her product is in high demand, allowing her to be able to acquire more fish to sell. At the same time, with the extra support, she will be able to enlarge her stand to allow for more stock and solidify her dream of building her own home. With the $250 loan, which she plans to repay in four months, she will purchase fresh fish by the sack, enlarge her shop and also buy a new parasol to protect herself and her goods from the sun.

Julia is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children. She has the support of her family and is certain she can accomplish her goal of having her own home, where she can transfer her business to and add more products to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Julia Rosario pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Mujeres Líderes”, vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia San Martín, distrito D. la Banda D. Shilcayo, su domicilio está ubicado en el Jr. Simón Bolívar Nº 327 en la av. San Juan. Se dedica a la venta al por menor D. pescado fresco en el Mercado Nº 2, ubicado en Jr. Santa Rosa cuadra 3. La oportunidad D. un préstamo en Manuela Ramos le permite prepararse para la época en que este producto tiene más demanda y así poder adquirir más pescado, asimismo con este apoyo podrá ampliar su local y vender más y concretar su sueño D. construir su propia casa. Con el préstamo D. S/. 700.00 el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará pescado fresco por sacos y ampliará su local, asimismo comprará una nueva sombrilla que la proteja del sol. La señora Julia tiene 48 años, vive con uno D. sus 2 hijos y su esposo. Tiene el apoyo D. su familia y actualmente se siente segura D. si poder alcanzar ha tener su casa propia y trasladar su negocio a dicho lugar y poder surtirlo con otros productos.

loans.use: Purchase fresh fish.

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Mr. Kossi Agbodazé is 36 years old, married, and has five (05) children. He has been working as a carpenter for 7 years. He bought a grain mill which allows the conversion of millet or maize into flour to make food paste. This business lightens the burden on the women of the neighbouring villages. The income drawn from this business will allow Mr. Agbodazé to educate his children and meet the family's needs. With this loan, Mr. Agbodazé is thinking of improving the equipment in his mill to make it more competitive.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Mr Kossi Agbodazé est âgé de 36 ans, marié et père de 5 enfants. Il exerce l’activité de menuisier depuis 7 ans. Il a achèté un moulin à gran qui permet de transformer le mil ou le mais en farine pour la fabrication de pates alimentaires . Cette activité allège la souffrance des femmes des villages environnants Le revenu tiré de son activité lui permet de scolariser ces enfants et faire face aux autres charges de famille. Avec le présent emprunt Mr Kossi Agbodazé pense aménager le local de son moulin pour rendre son service plus compétitif

loans.use: To fit out a mill office

loans.name: Maria Dina

texts.es:
Maria Dina is a founding partner of Banco Comunal Mujeres Creativas (Communal Bank for Creative Women) and dedicated to the sale of diverse kinds of vegetables and citrus fruits wholesale and retail at a post she has in a local market in Moyobamba, in the San Martín region for Peru. She decided to start this business because she needed to earn an income and grow as a person and a woman and support her household economically.

With the $875 loan, which she plans to repay in six months, she will purchase bags of cilantro, onion, corn, squash, peas, yucca, cabbage, carrots, lettuce, tomatoes and lemons, as well as other fresh produce of high quality to satisfy her clientele.

Maria is 54 years old and has three children, all who live with her and help her with the business and at home. She is content with what she does because she sells at a place where a lot of people gather and she can be in contact with friends and other people, so she enjoys her work. Her goal is to run a convenience store out of her home so she can take care of her business and her home at the same time and not neglect her household.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Maria Dina es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Mujeres Creativas, se dedica a la venta de verduras en sus diversas variedades y limones al por mayor y menor en el puesto que tiene en el mercado de abastos del distrito y provincia de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Decidió iniciarse en este negocio porque tenía la necesidad de trabajar para generar sus propios ingresos y crecer como persona y mujer y aportar económicamente en los gastos de su hogar. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará sacos de culantro, cebolla china, choclos, zapallos, alverjas, yuca, repollo, zanahoria, lechuga, tomates y limones además de otros productos frescos y de buena calidad para atender a su basta clientela. Tiene 54 años y 3 hijos que aún viven con ella y son quienes la apoyan en el negocio y la casa. Está contenta con lo que hace porque vende en un lugar donde acude bastante gente y puede estar en contacto con las personas y sus amistades, por eso disfruta de su trabajo. Su meta es tener un negocio en su casa de venta de abarrotes para poder compartir las actividades de la casa con su negocio y sobre todo no descuidar su casa.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables (cilantro, onion, corn, peas, squash, yucca, etc.)

loans.name: Maria Yraida

texts.es:
Maria, a member of the Communal Bank for Creative Women, lives in Moyobamba, in the San Martín region of Peru. She has a post in the city's central market where she sells spices and seasonings to prepare foods, as well as fruits and vegetables. After her husband passed away and knowing her abilities as a saleswoman, she decided to start her business because she needed to generate income to provide for her children.

With the $125 loan, which she'll repay in four months, she will purchase various products like pepper, cumin, garlic powder, bay leaf, oregano and salt by the pound and then sell them retail along with vegetables and other items. With her post diverse and well stocked she will be able to satisfy the demands of her customers.

Maria is 64 years old and has two children, both of whom live on their own. She is an optimistic, responsible and enterprising woman who longs to open another post in the market to sell more groceries.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Maria Iraida, socia del banco comunal Mujeres Creativas, vive en el distrito y provincia de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad donde vende especies o condimentos para la preparación de comidas, además de frutas y verduras. Al fallecer su esposo y conocedora de sus habilidades como comerciante decidió iniciar este negocio porque tenía la necesidad de generar sus propios ingresos para poder mantener a sus hijos. Con el préstamo de S/. 300.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará diferentes productos como pimienta , comino, ajinomoto, laurel, orégano y sal en kilos para luego venderlos al menudeo, así como verduras, entre ellas paltas y limones en sacos y guineos en racimos y de esa manera tener bien surtido su puesto de venta y poder satisfacer los requerimientos de sus clientes. Maria tiene 64 años, es separada de su esposo, tiene 2 hijos, todos ellos independientes. Es una mujer optimista, responsable y emprendedora, la cual anhela tener otro puesto en el mercado para la venta de abarrotes.

loans.use: Purchase spices (pepper, oregano, salt, etc.)

loans.name: Olinda

texts.es:
Olinda, member of the Communal Bank for Enterprising Women, lives in Moyobamba in the San Martín region of Peru. Her business is located in a popular market where she has sold desserts, fresh cheese and yogurt for the past four years. She is very well known for having high-quality products, which has allowed her to generate a strong clientele.

With the $425 loan, which she'll pay back in six months, she will purchase milk by the liter to prepare the cheeses and yogurt, and she will also buy flour and sugar by the sack, eggs, oil, butter and other products to help make the various popular desserts of the region.

She is 62 years old, widowed, and has six children, all who live on their own. She likes he work, but her goal is to have a well-stocked clothing and convenience store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Olinda, socia del Banco Comunal Mujeres Emprendedoras, vive en la región San Martín provincia y distrito de Moyobamba. El negocio está ubicado en el mercado Ayaymaman donde comercializa, desde hace 4 años, dulces, queso fresco y yogurt. Es muy conocida por brindar productos de muy buena calidad, lo que le ha servido para ganarse una buena clientela. Con el préstamo de S/.1,200.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará leche de vaca en litros para la preparación de los quesos y yogurt, además comprará harina y azúcar en sacos, huevos en jabas, aceite en litros, mantequilla en paquetes y otros productos para la preparación de variados dulces propios de la región. La señora Estela tiene 62 años, es viuda y tiene 6 hijos, todos ellos independientes. Le gusta el trabajo que hace pero anhela tener una tienda de abarrotes y vestidos bien surtida.

loans.use: Purchase milk, flour, sugar, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
Santos, a member of the Communal Bank for Enterprising Women, lives in Moyobamba, which is in the San Martín region of Peru. She has a post in the city's central market, where she sells bread and other products of high necessity. She was driven to start the business out of the need to generate her own income and help her husband with rearing and education their children. She had experience selling wholesale goods, but saw that retail had better profit margins so she switched to that.

With the $700 loan, which she will repay in six months, she will purchase various goods like bananas, yucca, oranges, lemons and other fruits and vegetables in high quantities so her post is well stocked and can satisfy her customers' demands.

Santos is 57 years old, divorced and has nine children, four of whom still live with her. She is a person with enthusiasm to do a good job no matter the effort. Her dream is to have her own home with a well-stocked convenience store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Santos, socia del banco comunal Mujeres Emprendedoras, vive en del distrito y provincia de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad en donde vende productos de pan llevar o de primera necesidad. Se inicia en el negocio motivada por la necesidad de generar sus propios ingresos y ayudar a su esposo en la crianza y educación a sus hijos. Tenía experiencia en la venta de productos al por mayor, pero observó que este tipo de negocio generaba mayores márgenes de ganancias por lo que decidió cambiar. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará diferentes productos como plátanos en racimos, yucas, naranjas y limones en sacos, frutas y verduras y de esa manera tener bien surtido su puesto de venta y poder satisfacer los requerimientos de sus clientes. Santos tiene 57 años , separada y con 9 hijos, 4 de los cuales aún viven con ella. Es una persona con entusiasmo para hacer las cosas bien sin medir esfuerzo, sueña con tener en su propia casa una bodega de abarrotes bien surtida.

loans.use: Purchase bananas, yuccas, oranges, lemons, etc.

loans.name: Mensavi

texts.fr:
Mr. Messavi Tsékpé is 28 years old, married, and has two (02) children. For 5 years he has been a blacksmith, a job he learned from his father over the course of four years. He makes hoes, machetes, and other tools for the farmers in his area. This business provides him with an income to meet the needs of his family.

This loan will allow him to improve the working conditions in his forge and to obtain more raw materials to meet the demands of his customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

M. Messavi Tsékpé est âgé de 28 ans, marié et père de 02 enfants. Depuis 5 ans il exercice l’activité de forgeron, métier qu’il a appris auprès de son père durant 04 ans. Il fabrique les houes, les coupe-coupe et autres produits pour les agriculteurs de la région. Cette activité lui procure les revenus pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

Le présent emprunt lui permettra d’améliorer les conditions de travail de sa forge et d’acquérir des matières premières pour face aux demandes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To fit out a forge and to buy raw materials to increase production

loans.name: Anali

texts.es:
Anali is 28 years old and has a fifth-grade education. She has a daughter who is dependent on her. In her convenience store she sells all types of groceries like oil, noodles, sugar, salt, tuna, etc. She also buys and sells grains and curd, which she sells around the region and also in the city of Trujillo. She is a member of a women's communal bank and received her first loan from there. It wasn't much, but with it she purchased 100 kilograms of curd and started earning a profit. With ensuing loans and profits she was able to start up her store little by little.

With the $450 loan, which she will repay in four months, she will purchase in Trujillo five bags of sugar, three sacks of rice, 46 kg of flour, three boxes of oil, five bags of noodles, two packages of salt, one box of tuna, and other items as well.

She started her business 10 years ago out of a country house in Salpo, in the La Libertad region of Peru. She had a tiny store that she started with the help of her parents. She later met her husband and left to live with him, and little by little she made enough money to slowly grow her store.

Anali dreams of selling more than just groceries items, like clothing or household appliances.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Anali Rodríguez F. tiene 28 años de edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado de primaria. Tiene una sola hija que aún depende de ella. En su bodega vende todo tipo de abarrotes como aceite, fideo, azúcar, sal, atún, etc. Además se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales y cuajada, los que vende por la zona y también en la ciudad de Trujillo. Es socia del banco comunal Progresistas, en el cual obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00. Este dinero lo invirtió en compara 100 Kg. de cuajada. Con los siguientes créditos y con sus ganancias fue implementando poco a poco una bodega. Con el préstamo de S/.1,300.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará en la ciudad de Trujillo 5 bolsas de azúcar, 3 sacos de arroz, 1 quintal de harina, 3 cajas de aceite, 5 bolsas de fideos, 2 paquetes de sal, 1 caja de atún y otras cosas. El negocio empezó hace 10 años en el caserío de Sauco distrito de Salpo provincia de Otuzco, departamento La Libertad, ahí tenía una pequeña tienda que había puesto con la ayuda de sus padres, posteriormente conoció a su esposo y se fue a vivir con el al barrio Miramar del distrito de Mache, ahí poco a poco hizo un pequeño capital con lo que sembraba y surtió lentamente la bodega. Su mayor sueño es vender algo más que abarrotes como por ejemplo ropa y utensilios para el hogar.

loans.use: Purchase groceries like sugar, rice, flour, oil, etc.

loans.name: Olga's Group

texts.en:
Lucy, Lucinda, and Olga have been associates of the community bank “Virgen Maria” for the past several years. Lucy is 20 years old and single. She has been selling cheese from a cart for the past four years.

Lucinda is 38 and married with three children who are all students. She sells groceries such as rice, sugar, milk, beans, oil, and soap in the town of Vilcashuman. Once a week she takes her merchandise and sells it in another small town named Huamanga.

Olga is 36 and married with two children who are still in school. She sells grains and different types of flour in the Playa Grau market. She buys things such as cornmeal, wheat, and other regional flours in the town of Acosynchos to sell at the market in Ayacucho.

Their loans are for 1200, 600, and 1400 soles respectively (3 soles = $1). They will invest these in: buying milk in order to make yogurt; butter, toothpaste, soft drinks, beer, grains; buying a small stand; and generally continuing to develop their businesses.

They plan to use their savings to buy a piece of land; a freezer; and to buy a house.

Lucy, Lucinda, and Olga say that their bank has taught them about responsibility and punctuality. They have learned how to treat their families, to care for their health, and to save. Furthermore, they feel content with their community bank.

Lucy, Lucinda, and Olga dream of studying to be nurses, and of building a home.

loans.use: continuing to develop their individual businesses

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr:
Mr. Kpénou Komlan is 38 years old, married, and has four (04) children who are in school. He has been a scrap iron worker for 6 years. This business provides him with income to meet the daily and educational expenses for his children. This loan will allow him to improve his workshop and to buy raw materials to meet the demands of his clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon

Mr Kpénou Komlan est âgé de 38 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants qui sont à l’école. Il exerce le métier de ferrailleur depuis 6 ans. Cette activité lui procure le revenu pour financer les charges courantes et scolaires de ses enfants. Le présent emprunt lui permet d’améliorer son atelier et d’acheter les matières premières pour la satisfaction de la clientèle

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make metal doors and to improve the workshop

loans.name: Blanca Amelia

texts.es:
Blanca Amelia is 54 years old and she studied through the fifth graD.. She lives in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the department of La Libertad. She has 2 children, but only one of them is still dependant on her.

The business she has is a small grocery store and also buys pigs. She kills the pigs on Fridays and then sells them at the Sunday market in Julcán district.

Her cousin invited her to join the “Progresistas” communal bank, from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00. She used the money to buy small animals like guinea pigs and chickens and chicks. She also bought a fresh cheese that she ages into a different type of cheese.

With a loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy 12 pigs and some rice and sugar that she needs for her grocery store.

Blanca is a member of a small cooperative restaurant in her neighborhood that is called “Corazón D. María”, and she is also president of her communal bank. Her greatest dream is to travel out of the country, to Spain, where she believes she would have better employment opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Blanca Amelia tiene 54 años D. edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado D. primaria. Vive en el distrito D. Mache, provincia D. Otuzco, departamento La Libertad. Tiene 2 hijos, pero sólo 1 depenD. aún D. ella. El negocio al que se dedica es una pequeña bodega y también a la compra D. cerdos, los cuales mata los viernes y los venD. en la feria que hay los días domingos en el distrito D. Julcán. Su prima la invitó a formar parte del banco comunal “Progresistas”, en el cual obtienen su primer préstamo D. S/300.00, este dinero lo utilizó para comprar animales menores como cuyes, gallinas y guachos, también para comprar cuajada que utiliza para la preparación D. quesos. Con el préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 12 cerdos y algo D. arroz y azúcar que hacen falta en su bodega. La señora Blanca es vocal del comedor D. su sector llamado “Corazón D. Maria” y también es presidenta D. su banco comunal. Su mayor anhelo es viajar al extranjero (España), ella cree que tendrá mejores oportunidades D. trabajo.

loans.use: To buy pigs and grocery items (rice and sugar)

loans.name: Mayra's Group

texts.en:
Marya and Nancy have been associates of the community bank “Alborada” for four months. Mayra is 23 years old and single, while Nancy is 31 and married with one 13-year-old daughter. For the past five years Mayra has had a store selling grocery items such as rice, sugar, tuna fish, soft drinks, sweets, beer, potatoes, and wheat which she buys in the nearby district of Quinua.

Nancy has been selling cosmetics from a catalogue for four years. She sells the items from her house and shares the profits with her sister.

Their loans are for 200 and 800 soles respectively (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying groceries, exchanging goods in the regional market of Cejelambras, buying corn, and wheat, expanding Nancy's supply of cosmetics, and fixing Nancy's husband’s car.

They plan to use their savings to further develop their businesses, and to buy healthy food for Nancy's daughter. Mayra and Nancy say that in their community bank they have learned values, responsibility, how to have friends, how to run a business, and how to work with other people.

Their dreams are to become professionals. Nancy is studying education, to be a responsible mother and daughter, and hopes to save for her daughter’s future. She hopes that her husband will not have to stop studying physical education, and she would like to have a bigger house.

loans.use: Their loans are for 200 and 800 soles respectively (3 soles = $1) which they will invest in buying groceries, exchanging goods in the regional market of Cejelambras, buying corn and wheat, expanding their supply of cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Catalina Del Carmen

texts.es: Catalina del Carmen Gutiérrez G. is from the city of Bluefields. She is 34 years old and is married to Santos Bonilla. They have 2 minor children who are studying. Mrs. Gutiérrez owns a small grocery store where she sells different types of cheese, cream, beans, corn, rice, and a cornmeal and cacao-based beverage mix called pinolillo. She has more than 11 years of experience. Her customers are people with families, owners of smaller grocery stores, and women who sell corn tortillas. They prefer her because she offers a variety of products. Mrs. Gutiérrez needs to buy 3 boxes of eggs at $20.00 per box, 1 quintal (100 pounds) of cheese at $80.00 per quintal, 1 drum of cream at $21.00 per drum, 50 pairs of cuajada (a soft, mild-flavored cheese) at $0.80 per pair, 14 pounds of pinolillo mix at $1.00 per pound, 5 100-pound sacks of rice at $35.00 per sack, and 10 100-pound sacks of corn at $11.00 per sack. With this inventory, she will be able to satisfy the demand from her customers, which has increased considerably in the last few months. It is worth noting that in our city people consume large quantities foods that are derived from dairy products, beans, rice, and corn.   Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer. La Sra. Catalina del Carmen Gutiérrez G. es de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 34 años de edad esta casada con el Sr. Santos Bonilla ambos tienen 2 hijos menores de edad que estudian. La Sra. Gutiérrez es propietaria de un tramo donde vende queso, crema, cuajada, frijoles, maíz, arroz y  pinolillo, tiene mas de 11 años de experiencia sus clientes son padres de familia, pulperías y las mujeres que venden tortilla de maíz, la prefieren por ofrecer una variedad de productos. En estos momentos la Sra. Gutiérrez necesita comprar 3 cajas de huevos a $ 20.00 dólar cada caja, 1quintal de queso a $ 80.00 dólares el quintal, 1 bidón de crema  a $ 21.00 dólares el bidón, 50 pares de cuajada a $ 0.80 centavos dólar el par, 14 libras de pinolillo a $ 1.00 dólar la libra, 5 quintales de arroz a $ 35.00 dólares el quintal y 10 quintales de maíz a $ 11.00 dólares el quintal con esta inversión podrá satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes que ha aumentado considerablemente en estos meses , cabe mencionar que en nuestra ciudad se consume en gran cantidad los productos derivados de lácteos , frijoles , arroz y maíz.

loans.use: To buy eggs, cream, cheese, pinolillo, rice, and corn

loans.name: Flor Elicenda

texts.es:
Flor Elicenda is 39 years old and she studied through fifth grade. She has a total of 5 children, and 4 of them are still dependant on her. She lives in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the department of La Libertad.

She buys pigs and raises them for slaughter. She then kills them and distributes their meat in different areas of the mountains. She also makes smoked ham and rawhides. She also buys sheep, fattens them up, and then sells them. Aside from this, she also cultivates barley, chayote squashes, wheat, potatoes, etc.

She is a member of the “Progresistas” communal bank, from which she has received several loans. The first loan was for S/.300.00, which she used to buy four young pigs.

With the loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy 10 pigs of varying sizes; she will also buy barley to feed them.

Flor’s greatest dream is to buy a motorcycle so that her husband can provide transportation to smaller towns in the Mache area, and thereby generate a better income for the household.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Flor Elicenda tiene 39 años de edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado de primaria, tiene en total 5 hijos y 4 aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache, Provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad Se dedica a la compra de cerdos para después de engordarlo, por cierto tiempo, los mata y distribuye la carne por diferentes lugares de la sierra, también prepara jamón (carne de cerdo ahumada) y cueros (piel de cerdo deshidratada), además compra carneros, los engorda y los vende. Aparte de ello se dedica a sembrar cebada, chocho, trigo, papas, etc. Ella es socia del banco comunal “Progresistas” en el que adquirió varios préstamos hasta la fecha, el primero fue de S/. 300.00, el cual lo utilizó para comprar 4 cerdos pequeños. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 10 cerdos entre grandes y pequeños, además comprará cebada para alimentarlos. El mayor sueño de la señora Flor es comprar una moto para que su esposo trabaje brindando servicio de movilidad a los caseríos de Mache y así obtener mayores ganancias en su hogar.

loans.use: To buy livestock (pigs, large and small) and feed for them

loans.name: Jesus Enma

texts.es:
Jesús Enma is 50 years old and she completed only primary school. She has three children who are still dependant on her. She lives in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the department of La Libertad. She raises small animals and also buys cattle, which she kills in order to sell their meat to buyers who come from Trujillo.

Jesús belongs to the “Progresistas” community bank, from which she received her first loan of S/. 300.00. With that money she bought 2 pigs, guinea pigs, and chickens. With a loan of S/. 1,300.00, which she will pay back in 4 payments, she will buy 2 calves.

Jesús began by selling small animals, and bit by bit, she used the profits to start buying cattle and that is how she got into this business.

Currently, she is the treasurer of the popular, small restaurant cooperative called “Corazón de María”. Her greatest dream is to put a well-stocked store in her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Jesús Enma tiene 50 años de edad, estudió sólo primaria completa. Tiene 3 hijos que aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco. departamento de La Libertad. Se dedica a la crianza de animales menores y a la compra de reses, las cuales las mata para luego vender la carne a comerciantes que van a comprar desde Trujillo. La señora Jesús pertenece al banco comunal “Progresistas” en el que recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, con este dinero compró 2 cerdos, cuyes y gallinas. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300.00, el cual pagará en 4 cuotas, comprará 2 teneros pequeños. La señora Jesús primero empezó vendiendo animales menores, después poco a poco con las ganancias y los posteriores préstamos fue comprando reses y así empezó a trabajar en este negocio. Actualmente es tesorera del comedor popular “Corazón de Maria”. Su mayor sueño es poner una tienda surtida en su casa.

loans.use: To buy two calves

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr:
Kokou Amégantsè, age 25, is single and is a shoemaker. He has been in this business for two years. With the current loan, Mr. Amégantsè intends to expand his shop and to buy raw materials and other supplies for his shoemaking work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Mr Amégantsè Kokou est âgé de 25 ans, non marié et est cordonnier .IL exerce cette activité depuis 2 ans .Avec le présent emprunt il compte agrandir son atelier et acheter des fournitures consommables pour son activité de coordonnerie

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making shoes to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
Juliana is 56 years old and she lives in the Mache district of Otuzco province, in L. Libertad department. Juliana has a son who still depends on her, and she only finished primary school.

The business she has currently is a small grocery store and she also sells small animals (such as rabbits, guinea pigs, ducks, and pigs), and sewing notions and supplies (zippers, buttons, threads, etc.).

She is a member of the “Progresistas” community bank, from which she obtained her first loan of S/.300.00. She used the money to travel to Julcán to buy chickens, guinea pigs, and ducks, which she sells in the city of Trujillo.

With a loan of S/. 2,500.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy perfumes, costume jewelry, and some groceries, to continue stocking her store. The loans that Movimiento ManueL. Ramos has given her have helped her to excel in her business when she was most in need, even when she was sick. He biggest dream is to buy a house in the city of Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

L. señora Juliana tiene 56 años D. edad, vive en el distrito D. Mache, provincia D. Otuzco, departamento L. Libertad. Juliana tiene un niño que aún depenD. D. elL. y sólo estudió primaria completa. El negocio al que se dedica actualmente es a L. venta D. abarrotes, animales menores (conejo, cuyes, patos y cerdos) y todo lo que es mercería (cierres, botones, hilos, etc.). Es socia del banco comunal “Progresistas”, en el cual obtuvo su primer préstamo D. S/.300.00, este dinero lo utilizó para viajar hasta Julcán a comprar gallinas, cuyes y patos, los cuales venD. en L. ciudad D. Trujillo. Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará perfumes, joyitas y algunos abarrotes para continuar surtiendo su tienda. Los préstamos que le ha brindado el Movimiento ManueL. Ramos L. ayudaron a sobresalir en su negocio cuando más lo necesitaba ya que por ese tiempo estaba delicada D. salud. Su mayor sueño es comprar una casa en L. ciudad D. Trujillo.

loans.use: Tjo buy merchandise (perfumes, costume jewelry) and grocery products

loans.name: Maria Berenice

texts.es:
Maria Berenice is 41 years old. She studied up until her Junior year of high school. Maria has 3 children which still depend on her for support. Her home is located in Ricardo Palma in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the state of La Libertad. Maria buys and sells cereals such as barley, wheat, dry potato, “chocho”, and broad bean. Additionally Maria raises and sells cattle, sheep and guinea pigs. These she sell in the Wholesaler’s Market in Trujillo.

Maria is one of the founding members and one of the main organizers for the communal banks in Mache. She is a member of the Communal Bank of Progressives, from which she received her first loan of S/. 300.00. With this money Maria began her first business and an ingredient for cheese manufacturing and sold it in the distinct villages of the area..

With this loan of S/. 2,500.00 ($875.00), which will be repaid in 4 months, Maria will purchase 14 sacks of wheat, 7 sacks of “chochos” and dry potato, and a few kilos of curds.

Maria dreams of building her own home in Trujillo and opening her own business there.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Berenice tiene 41 años de edad, estudió hasta el cuarto año de secundaria, tiene 3 hijos que aún dependen de ella. Su vivienda está ubicada en el caserío Ricardo Palma en el distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento La Libertad.

La señora Maria se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales tales como cebada, trigo, papa seca, chocho y habas, además de animales como reses y ovejas. Asimismo cría cuyes, los cuales los vende en el Mercado Mayorista de la ciudad de Trujillo.

Es socia fundadora y una de las motivadoras de la formación de bancos comunales en Mache. Pertenece al banco comunal “Progresistas”, en el cual obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00. Con este dinero inició su primer negocio, compró quesillo para preparar queso y venderlo por los distintos caseríos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará 14 sacos de trigo, 7 sacos de chochos, papa seca y unos cuantos kilos de cuajada.

La señora Maria sueña con construir su casa en la ciudad de Trujillo y ahí poner su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of cereals and dry goods for resale.

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Miss Abra K. is 25 years old and single. She has been a hairdresser for almost 3 years and plans on using the current loan to remodel her studio in order to make her customers feel more at ease.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mlle Abra K. est âgée de 25 ans , non mariée. Elle exerce la coiffure bientôt 3 ans et compte mieux aménager son atelier pour mieux mettre à l’aise ses clients avec le présent emprunt

loans.use: To remodel her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To  buy a motorcycle  and turn it into a Moto Taxi

loans.name: Martha Yolanda

texts.es:
Martha Yolanda is 44 years old. Martha completed high school and has 6 children, 3 of which still live at home. She lives in Ricardo Palma in the district of Mache, in the province of Otuzco, in the state of La Libertad. Martha owns a small grocery store in which she sells cooking oil, rice, milk, sugar, etc. In addition to these goods she purchases curds, animals and cereals (barley, wheat, etc) to sell whole sale in the more populated area, Campo Bello.

When Martha was single she had her own restaurant and a store in Campo Bello. After marrying her husband, she moved with him to their current home. For this reason she had to leave her other businesses and she began to plant and harvest agricultural goods. These she sold and over time raised enough to open a new store.

Martha is a member of the Communal Bank “Women of Mache,” from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00 ($100.00). She used the first loan to purchase 50 kilos of curds. With the new loan of S/. 1,000.00 ($350.00), which will be prepaid in 4 months, Martha will purchase a young milk cow and use the milk to create cheeses.

Martha is the fiscal manager of the communal kitchen, “Santa Rosa,” in Ricardo Palma and she is the secretary of the Mother’s Club in this same community. Her dream is to open a business in the city of Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Martha Yolanda tiene 44 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa, tiene 6 hijos en total, pero sólo 3 aún dependen de ella, vive en el caserío Ricardo Palma del distrito de Mache, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Tiene una bodega en la que vende abarrotes como aceite, arroz, leche, azúcar, etc. Además compra cuajada, animales y cereales (cebada, trigo, etc.) para venderlos al por mayor en la ciudad de Trujillo. Cuando era soltera tenía un restaurante y una tienda en el centro poblado Campo Bello, luego de casarse su esposo la llevó a vivir en su actual vivienda, por ese tiempo tuvo que dejar su negocio y se dedicó a la siembra, lo que cosechaba lo vendía y con las ganancias poco a poco fue reabriendo su tienda. La señora Martha es socia del banco comunal “Mujeres de Mache” , lugar donde obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, el cual lo invirtió comprando 50 kilos de cuajada. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará una vaca lechera tierna y de esta manera aprovechará su leche para hacer quesos. La señora Martha es fiscal del comedor popular “Santa Rosa” del caserío Ricardo Palma y es secretaria del club de madres de esta comunidad. Su sueño es poner un negocio en la ciudad de Trujillo.

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow.

loans.name: Yolanda Elsa

texts.es:
Yolanda Elsa is 44 years old. She completed 5th grade and has 8 children, only 5 of which still live with her. She lives in the district of Mache, in the Otuzco province, in the state of La Libertad. In Mache she has her own little farm in which she grows wheat, barely, and dry potato. She also raises swine, cattle, goats, chicken, ducks, and guinea pigs which she sells in the market.

Yolanda is a member of the Communal Bank of Progressives. She obtained her first credit from them for S/. 300.00 ($100.00) and purchased pigs to raise and sell at a higher price. With this loan of S/. 1,100.00 ($400.00), which will be repaid in 4 months, Yolanda intends to purchase small cows and the food that they will need.

As a small child Yolanda learned from her parents how to manage a farm, and she has dedicated herself to a farming life ever since. As an adult she incorporated the idea of raising animals and selling them at the fair in Mache. Little by little the profits from this project have added up and with the loans received she has been able to purchase additional animals and larger animals.

Yolanda is a member of the communal kitchen “Maria’s Heart.” Her dream is to own her own home in the center of the district of Mache.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Yolanda Elsa tiene 44 años de edad, estudió hasta el quinto grado de primaria, tiene 8 hijos, pero sólo 5 hijos dependen de ella, vive en el distrito de Mache provincia de Otuzco departamento La Libertad. En este lugar tiene su chacra donde siembra trigo, cebada, papa seca, también compra cerdos, reses y carneros para volver a vender en el camal, además cría animales menores como gallinas, cuyes y patos.

La señora Yolanda pertenece al banco comunal “Progresistas”. Con el primer crédito que obtuvo de S/.300.00 compró cerdos para engordarlos por cierto tiempo y sacarle mayor precio. Con el préstamo de S/.1,100.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará reses pequeñas y el alimento que estas necesitan.

Desde pequeña la señora Yolanda se ha dedicado a la siembra gracias a que sus padres le enseñaron como hacerlo. Cuando ya era mayor tuvo la idea de criar animales menores para venderlos en la feria de Mache y poco a poco con las ganancias que recolectaba y con los créditos que recibía compraba mas animales menores y a la vez unos cuantos de mayor peso.

La señora Yolanda es socia del comedor popular “Corazón de Maria”. Su mayor sueño es tener su propia casa en el centro del distrito de Mache.

loans.use: Purchase of animals and food to raise them on.

loans.name: Amavi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Amavi A. is 45 years old, married and the mother of 5 children. Her husband’s income is irregular and modest. Like other women in the village, she extracts palm oil that she then sells at the local market, which gives her enough income to fund more than half the family’s expenses. The current loan will help her increase her production significantly and therefore augment her income for the happiness of her children.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Amavi A. est âgée de 45 ans, mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Son mari a un revenu très irrégulier et modeste. Comme les autres femmes du villages, elle extrait l’huile de palm qu’elle revend sur le marché local , ce qui lu procure un revenu Pour financer plus de la moitié des charges familiales. Le présent emprunt l’aidera à augmenter sensiblement sa production donc augmenter ses revenus pour le bonheur de ses enfants

loans.use: To buy 40 bags of palm nuts from local villages to turn into palm oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy cosmetic  products and then sell them

loans.name: Kelly Amparo

texts.es:
Kelly is a member of the Community Bank of Triumphant Leaders. She lives Urb. Santa Rosa Mz. A Lt. 20, in the district of Yarina Cocha, in the state of Ucayali. Kelly is 45 years old, her husband is a welder. They have two grown children that continue to live with their home and help to support the family.

In order to help the family economically Kelly invested her first loan from “Manuela Ramos” in retail items from the producer “Union,” such as bread, cookies, sodas, and sweets. Currently she runs her own retail business selling all types of “Union” goods. Kelly wakes up very early each day in order to attend to her husband, tidy the house, prepare a lunch and then leave to sell her products.

With this loan of S/. 2,300 ($800.00), which will be repaid in 6 months, Kelly will purchase a large quantity of “Union” products and invest in her husband’s metal working shop.

Kelly is very happy. Her children have become professionals thanks to the business that she manages with the help of “Manuela Ramos” and she is able to enjoy the stable financial life she always hoped for.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Kelly pertenece al Banco Comunal Líderes Triunfadoras, vive en la Urb. Santa Rosa Mz. A Lt. 20 del distrito Yarina Cocha, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 45 años D. edad y es madre D. 2 hijos que ya son independientes, pero aún viven con ella y la apoyan en todo sentido. Es casada y su esposo es soldador. Para poder ayudar a su economía, Kelly, con el primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos deciD. invertir en la compra y venta D. productos Unión (panes, galletas, bebidas, y dulces).

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio D. compra y venta D. productos Unión en todas sus variedades. Se levanta muy temprano para atender a su esposo, asear su casa, preparar el almuerzo y D. ahí salir a repartir sus productos.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,300, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará mayor cantidad D. productos unión (panes, galletas, bebidas, dulces) e invertir en el taller D. soldadura D. su esposo.

Kelly está muy feliz porque sus hijos son profesionales gracias al negocio que ella maneja con el apoyo D. Manuela Ramos y pueD. gozar D. una estabilidad económica que tanto anhelaba.

loans.use: Purchase of breads, cookies, and sodas for resale.  Also, investment in a welding shop.

loans.name: Katerine

texts.es:
Catherine belongs to the “Líderes Triunfadoras” (Successful Leaders) community bank. She lives in the Callería district, in the department of Ucayali. She is 36 years old and is the mother of minor children who are dependant on her. She is separated and the income she has isn’t enough to cover the household expenses. For this reason, Katherine decided to invest her first Manuela Ramos loan, of S./300.00, in motor lubricants.

She currently has a business buying and selling wood. She gets up very early to help her children get ready and then takes them to school. She then goes to the mills in Manantay and seeks out her customers. In the afternoon, she takes care of her children.

With a loan of S/. 3,000.00, which she will pay in 6 months, she will buy a larger quantity of raw material (wood) of different species, such as quillobordon, quinilla, and capirona.

Katerine has been very content since she began working with Manuela Ramos. She feels like a self-realized person in all aspects of her life and she asks that you continue supporting women so that they can learn to value themselves for who they are.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Katerine pertenece al banco comunal Líderes Triunfadoras, vive en el Jr. César Vallejo 368 del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años de edad y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella, es separada y el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gasto del hogar, es así que Katerine con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 decide invertir en lubricantes de motos. En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de compra y venta de madera, para lo cual se levanta muy temprano para alistar a sus hijos y llevarlos a la escuela, luego se va a los aserraderos de Manantay en busca de sus clientes. En las tardes se dedica a su sus hijos. Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de materia prima (madera) de las diversas especies como quillobordon, quinilla y capirona. Katerine está muy contenta desde que está trabajando con Manuela Ramos, se siente una mujer realizada en todos los aspectos de su vida y pide que sigan apoyando a las mujeres para que aprendan a valerse por si mismas.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Abidé

texts.fr:
Mrs. Abidé K. has been widowed for 5 years and has 4 children. She has been extracting palm oil using traditional methods for over 10 years. This activity enables her to meet the educational needs and other expenses of her family. She is very dynamic and has already received three FECECAV microfinance loans, which she repaid without difficulty. The current loan will enable her to increase production and augment her income.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Abidé K. est veuve et mère de 04 enfants depuis 5 ans. Elle extrait l’huile de palm de manière traditionnelle depuis plus de 10 ans. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir aux besoins scolaires et autres charges de la famille. Elle est très dynamique et a déjà bénéficier trois crédit de FECECAV qu’elle a remboursé sans difficulté. Le présent emprunt lui permettra d’accroître sa production et augmenter ses revenus

loans.use: To buy 60 bags of palm nuts to make palm oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy macaroni , tomatoes etc.

loans.name: Carolina's Group

texts.en:
Maria, Karen, and Carolina have been associates of the community bank “Alborada” for the past year and a half, four months, and eight years respectively.

Maria is 34 years old. She is married and has five school-age children. She had a small grocery store for five years, but she decided to change businesses and planted a small farm in order to be closer to her children.

Karen lives with her partner and one son. For the past six months, she has had a small booth where she sells a typical food called "adobo" made from pork and onion. Before that she sold cell phones.

Carolina is 22 and lives with her partner and two children. She sells “chapla”, a typical bread from the region, as well as cheese, pork, corn meal, and other products which she transports to the La Parada market in Lima. In Lima she buys fruits such as papaya, mango, and grapes, which she sells in Ayacucho.

Their loans are for 400, 400, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1) respectively, which they will invest in buying farm animals, rice, sugar, beans, soap, milk, potatoes, and chicken in order to sell a larger variety of foods.

From their community bank, Maria, Karen, and Carolina have learned to be more responsible, punctual, and how to use money more effectively, improve their self-esteem, to be better mothers and to save.

Maria's dreams are to save more and have a bigger store, while Karen dreams of having a restaurant, and Carolina wants to work hard and improve the quality of life for her children.

loans.use: invest in and expand their various businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy charcoal and then sell it

loans.name: Fatima Argentina

texts.es:
Fatima Argentina is a single mother and has an 11-year-old boy. Due to the lack of income from her ex-husband, she found it necessary to start a business. Five years ago, she started a small business selling school supplies, which today has become a bookstore. She offers complete service to students who need it. She puts a lot of work into her business because her biggest dream is to be able to help her son get ahead and to provide him with a full education. Her store is located in the outlying market of Managua. She needs to buy school supplies for the school year that is coming up, and she needs to cover the demand of the clients who visit the market.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Fatima Argentina es madre soltera y tiene un niño de 11 años. Debido a la falta de ingreso por parte de su ex esposo se vió en la necesidad de poner un negocio, empezó hace 5 años montando una pequeña venta de útiles escolares, la cual hoy se ha convertido en una librería, en la cual ofrece un competo servicio a los estudiantes que lo requieren. Ella pone mucho empeño en su trabajo porque su mayor anhelo es poder sacar a su pequeño hijos, poder darle sus estudios completos. Su negocio lo tiene ubicado en el mercado periférico de Managua. Necesita comprar útiles escolares por la que la época escolar está por venir y necesita cubrir las demandas de los clientes que visitan el mercado.

loans.use: To purchase notebooks, backpacks, school uniforms, and school books

loans.name: Graciela's Group

texts.en:
Lidia, Zonia, and Graciela have been part of the community bank “Virgen Maria” for 9, 9, and 13 years respectively. In their community bank they have learned to be punctual, to save, to be responsible, how to educate their children, and how to have a healthy relationship with their husbands. They mentioned that in their community bank they feel like sisters.

Lidia is 34 years old and is married with five children. She has been selling, grains, animals, cheeses, and potatoes for nine years. She buys these things in the different open markets around the area and sells them in Ayacucho.

Zonia is 48 years old and is single. She travels to the market in the town of Putacca on Thursdays to buy grains and animals. She then sells these products in Ayacucho; she has been doing this for nine years. Zonia has also been raising animals for sale in the market.

On the other hand, Graciela sells meat and grains in the Magdalena market. She also sells, out of her house, products that she buys at the markets. In the past she sold food from the market in Pampa Cangallo market but had to start a new business when her husband changed jobs.

Lidia, Zonia, and Graciela need loans of 1200, 1200, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying potatoes, peas, habas (a local legume), cheese, pork, corn and wheat, and food for their animals.

They plan to use their savings to educate their children, improve their homes, and pay for medical care. Lidia dreams of having a house and more savings, while Zonia dreams of having land to cultivate and a house. Graciela dreams that her children will be professionals, and that she will have the capital to start another business.

loans.use: invest in and expand their various businesses

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
Don Miguel is married and has two children who are still minors, a 10-year-old-boy and a 17-year-old girl. HIs wife is a housewife and seamstress, a trade that lets her periodically contribute to their family's income. Don Miguel is a driver on a public transporation route, a position he has had for 8 years. His work day ends at 9:00 p.m. With a lot of sacrifice, Don Miguel has managed to construct his house. He would like this credit to be able to build a protective wall at the front part of his house to offer his family security and to protect them from robberies, which the Laureles Norte neighborhood is a frequent victim of.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Don Miguel es casado y tiene 2 hijos menores de edad, un niño de 10 años y una joven de 17 años. Su esposa es ama de casa y costurera, oficio con el cual periódicamente puede aportar ingresos a la familia. Don Miguel es conductor de una ruta de transporte colectivo, oficio en el cual ha estado 8 años, su día de trabajo termina a las 9:00 pm. Con mucho sacrificio Don Miguel ha logrado construir su casa, el crédito lo quiere para construir un muro de protección en la parte delantera de su casa, quiere brindarle a su familia seguridad y protegerlos de los robos de los que el barrio Laureles Norte es victima constantemente

loans.use: To purchase bricks, cement, and iron to build a wall for his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy clothes and materials to sell

loans.name: Susana's Group

texts.en:
Donatilda, Alfonsa, and Susana have been part of the community bank “Virgen Maria” for 5 years, 4 months, and 8 years respectively. In the community bank, they have learned to be responsible, punctual, and how to invest wisely in their businesses. They have also learned how to care for their children, have a positive relationship with their husbands, and to always smile.

Donatilda is 60 years old and is a single mother. She has four children, two of whom live with her. Donatilda sells fruit in the markets in the towns of Pampas and Ceccelambras. At the market she buys grains to sell in Ayacucho; she has had this business for three years.

Alfonsa is 30 and lives with her husband and three children. She owns a booth in the high school where she sells cookies and soft drinks. Furthermore, during school vacations she travels to other markets to buy grains and animals, which she sells in Ayacucho.

Susana is 50 years old. She is married and has 10 children, six of whom live with her. Susana sells bread, fruit, and vegetables in the markets around Ayacucho. From the markets she buys cheese, sheep, roosters, and grains to sell in Ayacucho. She learned this business from her grandmother.

Their loans are for 400, 800, and 1600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying bread, plantains, oranges, apples, avacados, sheep, pork, cheese, and potatoes.

They plan to use their savings to educate their children; decorate their homes; and treat illnesses. Donatilda dreams of having a roof for her house, and educating her children, while Alfonsa dreams of buying land to cultivate, having a bigger business, and having enough to eat. Susana dreams that her children will get married and be able to build their own houses.

loans.use: invest in and expand their various businesses

loans.name: Sesilia

texts.en: Sesilia is married with two children and she’s thirty eight years old. She had been running her business for three years before she found out about the loan program.  One of the challenges she had was not having enough money to buy the supplies she needed to make her business profitable.  And then she joined the program and got her 1st loan of $750ST and used it to buy all of the supplies she needed for running her business. The business is now making profits!  She is excited and says that she has the need for another smaller loan.  She sells her chips at the school during the week days and delivers them to the hospital at night time. She also sells them in the market on weekends days. She sells each for one tala(dollar) but she makes one hundred per day.  She is very excited and wants to keep her business growing.

loans.use: Buy ingredients needed to grow her chips business

loans.name: Epifania's Group

texts.en:
Aurea, Epifanis, and Delfina have been part of the community bank “Virgen Maria” for two years or less. In the bank they have learned how to invest money, to demand respect from people, how to care for their children, and how to save.

Aurea is 27 and has three children. She has had a grocery store in the town of Quicapata for 18 months. At first she sold things door to door but now she has been able to put a roof on her house and sell her products from there. She also used to sell cattle with her husband, but gave up that business to spend more time with her children.

Epifania is 41 and has six children. She sells meat in the city of San Francisco, which is located in the nearby jungle region. She travels to different markets to buy animals and later butchers them. She sells her meat at markets and different restaurants. She also buys "toccra", a product made from banana leaves and chewed like tobacco, which she sells in Lima.

Delfina is 55 and has 2 children. She sells clothing imported from the cities of Lima and Tacna. She sells her products at different markets around Ayacucho.

Aurea, Epifania, and Delfina need loans of 1000, 1200, and 1000 soles respectively (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying rice, squash, carrots, onion, sheep, pork, roosters, and a showcase to display products for sale.

They plan to use their savings to: buy more cattle; build a house; educate their children; and to continue developing their businesses. Aurea, Epifania, and Delfina dream of opening a grocery store in the jungle; that their children will be professionals; and that they will someday be able to travel to the town where they were born.

loans.use: invest in and expand their various businesses

loans.name: Encarnacion's Group

texts.en:
Emiliana, Maria Virginia, and Encarnación have been part of the community bank “Virgen Maria” for two years, four months, and one year respectively. In their community bank they have learned to organize their time, to be responsible, and how to educate their children.

Emiliana is 72 years old. She is widowed and has four children. Emiliana sells processed grains in the Nazarenas market of Ayacucho. She buys her products from the various mills in the region.

Maria Virginia is a single mother and a biologist by profession. She is 36 years old and has one son. She buys cochinilla, a local insect used to make red dye in the community of Simpapata and sells them to intermediaries. Maria also has a piece of land which produces "tuna", a fruit which comes from a cactus. Furthermore, she knits alpaca sweaters and baby clothing.

Encarnacion is 26 years old. She is single and is pregnant with her first child. She travels to local markets and buys grains and potatoes which she re-sells in Lima.

Emiliana, Maria Virginia, and Encarnación need loans of 400, 600, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which will be invested in buying wheat, flour, cochinilla, corn, peas, and taking care of the tunas.

They plan to use their savings to educate their children, and for whatever need presents itself. Emiliana, Maria Virginia, and Encarnacion dream that their children will be professionals, and that their businesses will continue to grow.

loans.use: Emiliana, Maria Virginia, and Encarnacion need loans of 400, 600, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which will be invested in buying wheat, flour, cochinilla, corn, peas, and taking care of the tunas.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen sells Juanes in the town of Bellavista, San Martin.  Juanes is a dish typical of the region which consists of chicken and rice wrapped and cooked in a palm leaf.  Carmen sells her meals in the street because she doesn’t own or rent a locale; she doesn’t think it’s necessary.  She’s been selling her Juanes for 12 years and has many loyal customers. She says she always provides customer-oriented service and the best tasting food.

Carmen is 44 years old, married and has three grown children.  With hard work and savings, Carmen and her husband were able to buy a small home and send two of their children to University.  She started the business to help her family financially so their children would have more opportunities than they had previously.  

Carmen is a member of the community bank Mujeres del Futuro and is requesting a loan of NS./ 1000, that she will pay off in 6 months.  With the loan she would like to buy large quantities of rice, chicken, and cooking oil.  The large quantities will lower the cost necessary to prepare the Juanes and help her save even more money.  Carmen would one day like to improve and expand her family's home.

loans.use: Buy large quantities of rice, chicken and cooking oil.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
Flor has a business selling agrochemicals in Bellavista, San Martin.  Bellavista is the largest town in a rural area surrounded by large and small farms so her products are always in high demand.  She says that her store is special because she has products that aren’t as harmful to the environment.  The land in the area has been overworked and is contaminated, so crops don’t grow as well as they used to.  She has many clients that come to her store because they know her products will help prevent further damage to their land.

Flor is 35 years old and married.  She doesn’t have any children but has nine siblings and many nephews and nieces.  Her husband is very supportive and helps her with most of the manual labor.  She loves her business and is happy she is able to help the rest of her family who aren’t as fortunate.  Flor is also happy with all the people she’s helped and friends she’s made through her business.

A member of the community bank Mujeres del Futuro, Flor is requesting a loan of S/ 2500, that will pay in 6 months.  With the loan she would like to buy herbicides, fertilizer, and medicines for livestock.  These products are in high demand and she is running low.

loans.use: Buy herbicides, fertilizer and medicines for livestock

loans.name: Megui

texts.en:
Megui rents a space in the center of Bellavista, San Martin, where she sells jewelry such as earrings, necklaces, and bracelets.  Her husband is a master jeweler and they work together in the shop.  Megui is in charge of sales while her husband designs and manufactures the impressive works of art.  Megui is a good sales woman; she has a lot of prior experience including the sales of cosmetic goods.

Megui is 37 years old and has one daughter.  The family is very close and they work together all day long.  Megui and her husband never had the opportunity to study at a University but are determined to send their daughter to study in Lima when she is older.  They all work very hard and save for the future.

A member of the community bank Mujer Bellavista, Megui is seeking a loan of S/ 1300, that she will pay off in 6 months. She will use this loan to buy materials to make their jewelry such as gold, silver, beads, thread, and new tools.  They are certain the loan will help them take their business to the next level.  They also have the dream of one day selling their jewelry in the United States and Europe.

loans.use: Buy materials to make jewelry and new tools.

loans.name: Tomasita

texts.en:
Tomasita runs a business selling fish from her home and in the streets.  She sells her fish to the population of Bellavista, San Martin.  The fish she sells includes local species and species from the coast which she buys from a wholesaler.  She is an experienced sales and business woman; she grew up running different businesses with her father.

Tomasita is married and has three children.  Her husband and children are supportive of her business and help with manual labor.  She started the business eight years ago to help her husband earn money and send her children to Universities.  Tomasita never had the opportunity to study but is determined to give all her children a brighter future.  She works very hard to balance her business and domestic work.  It’s not unusual if she gets out of bed at 3 a.m. to start preparing for the day.

A member of the community bank Las Vencedoras, Tomasita is requesting a loan of S/ 1000 to invest into her business, that she will pay off in 6 months.  With the loan she would like to buy the highest quality Tilapia, Badre, Toa, and Bochica.  These fish are favorites of the region and in high demand.  She will also seek to expand the variety of her products and purchase more fish from the coast.

loans.use: To buy fish.

loans.name: Thi Linh

texts.vi:
Ms Lĩnh is 21 years old. She is married and has 1 daughter. She operates an internet cafe and a hairdressing salon. Her husband handles the internet cafe and she, the salon. She also helps out her husband when she is free. She is applying for a loan to buy new chairs for her shop. The internet cafe is quite busy because only the rich people have internet at home, all the others have to go to an internet cafe either for chatting or surfing. She has a lot of customers who frequent her cafe. She had to borrow capital from her family members to open the internet cafe but she has already paid back since then. She likes the payment arrangement of Binh Minh (SEDA)

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lĩnh, 21 tuổi, đã lấy chồng và có một con gái. Chị kinh doanh quán internet và làm nghề cắt tóc gội đầu. Chủ yếu, chồng chị trông quán còn chị làm nghề cắt tóc, thỉnh thoảng chị thay phiên anh lúc rảnh rỗi. Chị vay vốn vể để mua thêm ghế ngồi vì nó đã quá cũ. Chị kinh doanh internet cũng khá tốt vì ở huyện chỉ những nhà giàu mới có nối mạng, còn phần đồng phải ra quán khi muốn chat hay có việc gì đó. Khách đến quán chị khá đông. Khi mới mở quán, chị phải vay bà con họ hàng, nhưng giờ chị đã trả hết nợ. Chị thích vay vốn của Chương trình tài chính vi mô Bình minh vì chị thấy cán bộ ở đây rất nhiệt tình.

loans.use: Buy chairs for her internet cafe

loans.name: Thi Ngoan

texts.vi:
Mrs. Ngoan, 44, has 3 children. The oldest is working now and the other two are still in school. Years ago she sold chè nước, kind of Vietnamese desert. Then she changed to selling phở, a popular Vietnamese noodle soup, 5 years ago. She has a phở kiosk at the Chờ market where she serves phở from early morning to 4pm everyday. Her husband helps her to run the business in the morning, then rushes home to tend her pig stock. She uses the left over food from her stand and buys more from neighbor stands as feed for her pigs. That feed would make pigs grow faster and have tastier meat. She like to borrow money from Binh Minh because it allows her to make weekly payment.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Cô Ngoan, 44 tuổi, có 3 con, 1 người đã đi làm còn 2 người còn đang đi học. Trước kia, cô bán hàng chè nước, hiện nay, cô chuyển sang nghề bán hàng bún phở được 5 nă,. Cô có 1 kiôt ở chợ Chờ, cô thường bán từ sáng cho tới 4h chiều. Chồng cô cũng tham gia phụ bán hàng, giúp cô vào buổi sáng, sau đó về nhà chăn lợn. Cô tận dụng thức ăn thừa, và mua thêm ở các hàng ăn khác để chăn nuôi, nên lợn chóng lớn và ngon thịt hơn khi chăn bằng cám công nghiệp. Cô thích vay của chương trình tài chính vi mô Binh Minh vì được trả dần hàng tuần.

loans.use: mua hàng để bán Bún, Phở

loans.name: Thi Thanh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Thành, 42, is married and has 2 children. Her husband, Mr. Hòa, is the chairman of the city council of Chờ. She has a footwear shop at the central market. The shop caries footwear from Bitis, the most famous brand in Vietnam. Her shop has good reputation and is popular. She would like to take out a loan from Binh Minh to replenish her shop getting ready for Tết.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Thành ,42 tuổi, đã có chồng và có 2 con. Chồng chị là anh Hòa, làm Chủ tịch ủy ban thị trấn Chờ, chị mở cửa hàng bán giầy dép tại cổng chợ trung tâm. Chị làm đại lý cho hãng bitis rất nổi tiếng tại Việt Nam. Ở cửa hàng chị có tất cả các mặt hàng như giầy da, giầy thể thao, dép... Khách hàng rất thích mua hàng của chị vì sự uy tín của cửa hàng. Chị vay vốn để nhận thêm hàng bán vào dịp Tết sắp tới. Chị vay của chương trình tài chính vi mô Binh Minh vì được tham gia cũng nhóm, được sinh hoạt cụm và vay vốn lâu dài.

loans.use: Buy goods to replenish the footwear store

loans.name: Basheeran's Group

texts.en: My name is Basheeran A.. I have lived all my life in a small town in Pakistan famous for its saints, Pakpattan. I am married and a mother of six. My husband sells grocery on his small store. He needs to buy plastic bowls, plates and flour for his shop; therefore, we request a loan. I am responsible for the loans of few other women and their families: Momina B. will buy a wagon to offer transport services to the people of this area. Zahida N. will invest the loan in their fields. Khareen B. will pay off the remaining money of the wagon they bought. Naseem B. will invest the loan to improve their fruits business. Sakina B. will buy tires for their tires shop.

loans.use: To buy plastic bowls, plastic plates and flour

loans.name: Koser's Group

texts.en:
I am Koser P.. I am a mother of two: one boy and one girl. My son is eight and is in grade one while my daughter is not of school age yet.  My husband works at a nearby sweets shop for a small salary. I request a loan to buy a donkey cart to sell vegetables on it.
I know all the women in my loan group, they are nice and work very hard: Sakina B. wants to expand their meat shop. Waziran B. will use the loan to buy a cow. Irshad B. will buy a donkey cart to transport goods on order from one place to another. Allah M. will buy a cabin for their rickshaw.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Thi Bay

texts.vi:
Mrs. Bẩy, 41 years old, sells seasonal fruits. Everyday she buys fruits by riding a moped scooter to the wholesale place. If she is busy she can make a call and fruits will be delivered. While she sells fruits at the near by market, her husband tends a bicycle repair shop and her children are at school. She can borrow money from Binh Minh to buy fruits without credit and she also can have a long term loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Bẩy, 41 tuổi, đi chợ bán hoa quả. Mùa nào chị bán hoa quả đấy. Mỗi ngày một lần, chi đi lấy hàng bằng xe máy. Nếu bận chị có thể gọi điện sẽ có người mang hàng đến tận nơi. Chị thường bán ở chợ gần nhà, chồng chị mở cửa hàng sửa xe máy, các con chị còn đang đi học. Chị vay vốn để mua thêm hàng về bán, vay trả góp, chị sẽ không còn lo lắng phải trả nhiều tiền khi đến hạn, đặc biệt chị được vay vốn lâu dài không cần phải thế chấp khi có nhu cầu.

loans.use: Buy fruits

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en: I am Mussarat B. from the small metropolis Pakpattan, Pakistan.  I own a house here and live with my family. My family comprises of one son, one daughter and my husband.  My daughter attends kindergarten while my son is too young to attend school at the present.  My husband works as a ticket collector in a local transport. I request a loan for my brother, who is a blacksmith and manufactures iron boxes. My group members are my neighbors and I completely trust them. Imam H. needs a loan to buy a donkey cart. Karam Bhari plans  to buy a rickshaw. Naseem B. will use the loan to repair their rickshaw.

loans.use: To expand brother's business

loans.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en: My name is Kaneez Y.. Neither I nor my husband are educated but still we are familiar with its importance.  Therefore, we send our kids to school. It is because we do not want them to do menial jobs like us but rather obtain a high level of success in their lives. I have five boys and one girl. My husband is a driver at someone’s house. We have also a rickshaw that we rent to supplement our income. Now our rickshaw is need of repairs and we need a loan for this purpose. I request loans for my loan group members as well: Parween H., who will use the loan to buy a donkey cart. Haleema B., who will invest the loan to start a barber shop and Shamim B. who will also buy a donkey cart to transport animal fodder on it.

loans.use: To repair rickshaw

loans.name: Mahsud

texts.en:
M. Mahsud is 35 years old. He is married and has two children both going to school. Mahsud’s wife is the housekeeper and is looking after the kids.

Mahsud is the only bread-winner in the family. He is cooking kebabs and is running a small open café to sell them. Mahsud has been a very active client of IMON since March, 2006. His first loan was in the size of $250.00 US Dollars. Mahsud had never had any delinquencies or violations.

A difficult economic position forced Mahsud to start this business which he has been running for 5 years. The business generates stable income to support his family and improve their living conditions. Today Mahsud requests $1000.00 US Dollars which he will repay in 6 months. He is planning to purchase inventory like plates, dishes, tables and chairs to expand his business and to improve the conditions of his small open café for the clients. Mahsud would like to thank everyone for their support.

loans.use: Purchasing of inventory for his café i.e. plates, dishes, tables and chairs.

loans.name: Thu Hang

texts.vi:
Ms. Hằng, 35 year old, divorced, raises a daughter by herself. She is a seamstress. At evening, she makes extra living by selling barbecue chicken feet. She would like to borrow money for buying material. She’s never taken out a loan from Binh Minh and this is the first time. The repayment plan is convenient for her.

Translated from Vietnamese by nguN., Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hằng, 35 tuổi, đã có chồng và 1 cô con gái. Tuy nhiên chị đã ly dị, hiện tại chị nuôi con một mình. Thu nhập hàng ngày của chị là làm may, tối chị lại bán chân gà nướng. Chị vay vốn về mua thêm vải may cho khách. Chị chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đây, tuy nhiên, lần này, chị lại tham gia vay vốn của chương trình tài chính Binh minh vì chị thấy nó rất thuận tiện trong việc hòan trả.

loans.use: Buy material

loans.name: Fatoh

texts.en:
