G. Fatoh is 49 years old. His wife, who is a seamstress, and he raised 2 sons. Both sons are already married.  

For 32 years Fatoh has been involved in the business of repairing  vehicles and also selling them. He started as the master and gradually managed to open his own repair shop. Fatoh is well-known in his neighborhood as an excellent master. He tries to fix any problem and the prices for his services are quite fair which attracts lots of clients. All this allows Fatoh to generate stable income for his family, to help his sons and to buy small presents any time his grandchildren come to visit him. 

Fatoh has been provided with several loans by IMON. He is a very accurate and positive client. Today Fatoh requests $900.00 US Dollars to purchase spare parts for the repair of cars. Fatoh plans to pay the loan in 12 months and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for his auto repair business

loans.name: Ni Luh Widiani

texts.id:
Living in the village makes Ni Luh Widiani and her husband, Putu Rauh, who works as a handyman, to do other work that can help generate other income for the family besides income coming from her husband. Their effort is by raising pigs. Widiani bought 4 piggies for Rp. 1 million for fattening. After 4 months her pigs are sold for Rp.800,000,- to Rp. 1,000,000,- each. Net profit for each is Rp.150,000,-. After she cleans the pig pen, Widiani feeds her pigs two times a day, in the morning and afternoon. Profit coming from selling the pigs is used to meet her family daily necessities, for education of her 10th grade child, and for her 4 years-old. Her semi-permanent house was built on her own land. Widiani plans to use loan from Dinari to buy more pigs and the feed.

Translated by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

Hidup di desa membuat Ni Luh Widiani bersama suaminya, Putu Rauh, yang hanya bekerja sebagai tukang, mengharuskannya membuka usaha yang dapat membantu menambah penghasilan lain disamping usaha yang dilakukan oleh suaminya.Usaha itu adalah memelihara babi. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Widiani membeli 4 ekor babi dan dipelihara sebagai penggemukan . Setelah dipelihara selama 4 bulan babinya laku terjual dari harga Rp. 800.000 sampai Rp. 1.000.000,- perekor. Keuntungan bersihnya sebesar Rp.150.000.- perekor. Widiani memberi makan babinya sebanyak dua kali sehari pada pagi dan sore hari. Dan Widiani membersihkan kandangnya sebelum babinya diberi makan. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhannya dan juga untuk pendidikan anaknya yang duduk dikelas I SMA dan yang kedua belum sekolah masih berumur 4 tahun. Rumahnya dibangun ditanah sendiri dengan bangunan yang cukup permanen. Harapannya dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, Widiani akan membeli beberapa bibit babi lagi dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan.

loans.use: To buy pigs and the feed

loans.name: Kawala 1B(A) Group

texts.en:
Hellen is married with eight children. She wants to build rental houses with the extra business profits.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Ni Wayan Suarmi

texts.id:
Eventhough Ni Wayan Suarmi husband, I Ketut Suada, is a public servant; she determines to help her husband by opening a kiosk in front of her house. She sells almost all daily groceries in her kiosk. Besides running the kiosk, she also raises pigs at her backyard. Started with Rp. 1 million she bought 4 piggies for fattening which now only left one pig after selling the other three. Suarmi feeds her pigs with paddy shell and oat/wheat powder, and banana leaf and trunk. After 4 months, her pigs are ready for sale with profit Rp. 200,000 each. The money is used for her family daily expenses. She plans to buy piggy and breeder as well.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer

Walaupun sebagai istri seorang Pegawai Negeri, Ni Wayan Suarmi tetap ingin membantu suaminya, I Ketut Suada. Suarmi membuka usaha warung didepan rumahnya. Segala kebutuhan sehari-hari ada di warungnya. Disamping usaha warung Suarmi juga memelihara babi dibelakang rumahnya. Dengan modal awal Rp.1.000.000,- Suarmi membeli 4 ekor bibit babi dan dipelihara sebagai penggemukan. Sekarang babinya sudah dijual dan tinggal 1 ekor babi penggemukan. Disamping memberi dedak padi dan dedak gandum, Suarmi juga memberikan daun-daunan seperti daun pisang , daun talas, dan batang pisang. Setelah dipelihara 4 bulan babinya siap dijual. Keuntungan yang diperoleh sebesar Rp.200.00,- per ekor. Keuntungan ini dipakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya. Suarmi berencana membeli bibit babi lagi dan juga induk

loans.use: To buy piggy and breeder

loans.name: Ni Ketut Mariasih

texts.id:
Living in a village far from the city, according to Ni Ketut Mariasih, is very suitable to raise pigs. Her husband, I Putu Pasek whom work is a construction worker, supports the idea . Mariasih started the business with Rp. 1 million and took a breeder and 4 piggies for fattening. She plans to expand her business by adding more pigs to increase profit considering the high market price of pork. She will use the profit coming from the business to support her family daily expenses, put her child in school, and buy necessities for her infant. She lives in a modest house built on her parents land. Mariasih plans to use loan from Dinari to buy more pigs and the feed.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

Tinggal di desa yang cukup jauh dari keramaian, membuat Ni Ketut Mariasih sangat cocok beternak babi. Usaha ini didukung pula oleh suaminya, I Putu Pasek yang bekerja sebagai tukang bangunan. Untuk memulai usahanya, Mariasih memelihara induk babi dan 4 ekor anak babi untuk penggemukan. Dengan modal awal sebesar Rp. 1.000.000,-. Mariasih memulai usaha ini. Mariasih berencana untuk memperbesar lagi usahanya dengan menambah jumlah babi yang akan dipelihara agar keuntungan yang didapat lebih banyak mengingat saat ini harga daging babi dipasaran tergolong cukup mahal. Keuntungan yang diperoleh dipakai untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya dan juga untuk pendidikan anaknya yang masih sekolah dan yang paling kecil masih balita. Rumahnya sangat sederhana dibangun di atas tanah milik orang tuanya. Harapannya dari pinjaman yang diperoleh dari Dinari, Mariasih akan membeli bibit babi lagi dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan.

loans.use: To buy piggy and the feed

loans.name: Nasim

texts.en:
G. Nasim shall turn 26 in January. He is married and has a wonderful baby who is only one year old. His wife is the seamstress who sews the national dresses.  

Nasim's father owns a car repair shop and Nasim has been helping him since he was 11 years old.  After being trained by his father for all this years, Nasim made the decision to start his own repair shop where he is fixing cars and also is involved in the business of selling the cars. His repair shop is well-known and Nasim has been a very popular master in the city for several years. His business is quite stable and generates significant income for his family allowing them to improve their living conditions at the same time. 

This is the third loan to Nasim provided by IMON. Nasim has been an accurate client managing his loans without violations. Now Nasim requests $900.00 US Dollars as he needs spare parts to repair cars. Nasim thanks all for their support and promises to pay the loan in 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for his auto repair business

loans.name: Kawala 1B(B) Group

texts.en:
Mayi is 39 years old and married with five children. She sells used shoes. With the extra profits she hopes to make from expanding this business, she wants to pay school fees for the children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes thus expand her business

loans.name: Kawaala 1B(C) Group

texts.en:
Fiona is 28 years old and married with four children. She owns a retail shop and would like to expand the inventory. With the extra profit, she wants to build a home for her family.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock in her retail shop

loans.name: Jero Tirta

texts.id:
Jero Tirta is a housewife that works hard to help her husband, Gusti Kade Putrayasa, who works as a farmer. Jero Tirta started raising pigs with just 1,000,000 given to her by her husband. She used that money to purchase a sow that she took special care of. After 6 months of care, the sow gave birth to 7 piglets. This accomplishment made Jero Tirta even more diligent in her work and more enthusiastic about the potential of her business. Every day she cleans the pig pen, brings food to them in the form of leaves and a mixture of rice and wheat byproduct from a mill (a common source of animal feed). After the piglets are one and a half months old, they are sold at the market price of 250,000 Rupiah a piece. She also has the boars and selected pigs that she will keep and raise for about 5 months until they are fattened. From selling the boars alone, she believes she can make as much as 1,750,000. She would use the profits to pay for the further education of her daughter who is in her third year of primary school. She would also use the profits to fulfill their daily needs. Jero Tirta hopes to borrow capitol to purchase boars for fattening and the remaining funds for purchasing pig feed.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Jero Tirta seorang ibu rumah tangga yang ulet bekerja untuk membantu suaminya, Gusti Kade Putrayasa, yang bekerja sebagai petani. Jero Tirta memelihara babi dengan modal awal Rp. 1.000.000,- yang diperolehnya dari suaminya, lalu uang itu dibelikan induk babi dan dirawat dengan baik. Hasilnya, setelah dipelihara selama 6 bulan induk babinya melahirkan anak babi sebanyak 7 ekor dan ini membuat Jero Tirta semakin rajin dan lebih bersemangat lagi dalam menjalankan usaha ini. Setiap hari kandangnya dibersihkan kemudian diberi makan berupa dedaunan disamping memberi dedak padi dan dedak gandum. Setelah anak babi berumur satu setengah bulan anak babi dapat dijual dengan harga pasaran Rp 250.000 per ekor yang masih berupa bibit atau calon babi yang nantinya aka dipelihara lagi sekitar 5 bulan untuk penggemukan.Dari hasil penjualan bibit babi saja dapat diperkirakan Jero Tirta akan mendapatkan pemasukkan sebesar Rp 1.750.000 Keuntungannya dipakai untuk pendidikan anaknya yang masih duduk dikelas 3 SD. Dan juga untuk pemenuhan kebutuhan setiap hari . Harapan Jero Tirta dengan pinjaman dari Dinari Jero Tirta akan membeli bibit babi untuk penggemukan dan sisanya untuk biaya pakan.

loans.use: To purchase boars and pig feed

loans.name: Muk Yemusumba B Group

texts.en:
Rita is 33 years old and married with three children. She offers tailoring services. She intends to use the extra business profits to pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines

loans.name: Muk Yemusumba A Group

texts.en:
Hayusha is 30 years old and married with two children. She sells new clothes. With the profits from her business she intends to buy a piece of land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase fabric for her clothing business

loans.name: Usupov

texts.en: Usupov A. lives in Spitamen, Tajikistan. He is married and has 2 children. Hearing a lot of successful stories from the friends on the MicroInvest loan procedure Mr.Usupov decided to take a loan for  business development. He improved the existing situation and the business stability and income increase helped him to return the previous loan. Mr.Usupov was engaged first in the agricultural products and rice cultivation and selling, but thanks to the MicroInvest loan he started a new  business. Now he is engaged in the home business of  wood products manufacturing and selling (window framing, doors, plinths and etc.). Now Mr.Usupov requests the loan of $500 for his wood products making business development that would permit him to open his own trade outlet.

loans.use: for the wood products making business development

loans.name: Muk Yemusumba C Group

texts.en:
Esther is a single mother of six children. She sells used clothes. She wants to use the extra profits to pay school fees for the children and buy a piece of land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell in the store

loans.name: Ni Wayan Sariani

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Sariana takes care of her family and is also very active in her work. Her husband, I Wayan Tama, owns a furniture crafting business. Ni Wayan Sariani does not just sit quietly at home while her husband works. Every day after she finishes her work as a housewife - cooking, managing all of the affairs of the household and caring for their two daughters who attend high school and primary school respectively, she joins her husband to help him with his work. Her husband gets orders to make Sanggah (household shrines used in the practice of Hinduism), cabinets, tables, chairs and more. To help reduce the strain on her husband, Sariani helps him by doing the finishing work on the furniture that her he crafts. This includes painting the furniture, amongst other things. Sariani would like to borrow funding to be used to purchase the basic supplies they need for their business like wood, paint and other items. With a only 20,000 Rupiah per day from her husband, she takes care of all of her family's needs.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Wayan Sariani adalah sosok ibu rumah tangga yang senantiasa giat berkerja.Walaupun suaminya, I Wayan Tama, sudah mempunyai usaha Meubel sendiri . Ni Wayan Sariani tidak tinggal diam saja dirumahnya. Setiap hari sesudah menyelesaikan perkerjaan sebagai ibu rumah tangga, memasak dan menyiapkan segala sesuatunya di rumah dan juga untuk kedua putrinya yang masih sekolah pada tingkat atas dan tingkat sekolah dasar dasar, barulah Sariani membantu pekerjaan suaminya sebagai usaha Meubel. Pesanan yang diterima meubel suaminya seperti membuat Sanggah ( Pura tempat untuk sembhayang umat Hindu ), lemari, meja kursi dll.Untuk mengurangi biaya penegeluaran tenaga kerja, maka Sariani membantu pekerjaan suaminya. Pekerjaan yang dilakukan yaitu pekerjaan untuk tahap-tahap penyelesaian / finishing dari pekerjaan suaminya. Misalnya mengecat, dan pekerjaan finishing lainnya. Dana pinjaman yang diperoleh pada Yayasan DINARI dipakai untuk membeli bahan baku yang akan dipergunakan seperti kayu, cat dan yang lainnya dalam menunjang usaha bersama suaminya. Dengan upah sebesar Rp. 20.000,- dalam satu hari dari suaminya Sariani pergunakan untuk mencukupi keperluan keluarganya.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies for the business

loans.name: Ni Ketut Kodi

texts.id:
Ni Ketut Kodi is a mother, and at the same time acts as a father to her two children since it has been a long time since her husband has lived with them. To provide for her children, Ni Ketut Kodi sells clothing around her village and has also opened a sewing business from her home which has been their main source of income. She also travels over 10km from her home to the city of Negara, Bali via Ojek (motorcycle taxi) to sell her merchandise. To sell her merchandise she must walk to and around all of the surrounding villages. This is because her merchandise is in high demand. Her profits are as much as 250,000 Rupiah per week, which are used to pay for her family's day-to-day living expenses. She also uses her remaining time to make and repair clothes for her customers. She would like to borrow capitol to purchase additional merchandise to diversify her offerings and in-turn, greatly increase her profits.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Ketut Kodi adalah seorang ibu dan sekaligus sebagai Ayah dari dua orang anaknya karena sudah sejak lama ditinggal oleh suaminya. Untuk menyambung hidup bersama anaknya Ni Ketut Kodi berjualan baju keliling di sekitar kampungnya dan juga membuka usaha menjahit dirumahnya yang merupakan mata percaharian utama keluarga ini. Barang dagangan yang dijual diperoleh di kota Negara yang jaraknya 10 Km dari tempat tinggalnya dengan mengunakan Ojek. Untuk menjajakan barang dagangannya biasanya berkeliling dengan berjalan kaki kedaerah pedesaan-pedesaan di sekitar tempat tinggalnya. Sebab dengan cara seperti itulah biasanya barang dagangannya akan laku terjual. Keuntungan yang diperoleh setiap minggu sebesar Rp 250.000 yang nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup mereka setiap hari. Dan dirumahnya, Ni Ketut Kodi juga mempergunakan waktu luangnya untuk menservis baju para langganannya. Modal Pinjaman dari Yayasan DINARI ini dipergunakan untuk membeli barang dagangan agar lebih banyak lagi dan lebih bervariasi agar jumlah langanannya bertambah banyak.

loans.use: To purchase a wider range of inventory

loans.name: Anak Agung Kadek

texts.id:
In order to have the necessities of day to day life, A. and her family run a small store. A.'s husband is a farmer whose work is never steady. If he is not called off on a new work assignment, he spends his time tending to the garden that he inherited from his parents. In her store, A. sells items necessary in the day-to-day lives of the people in her area. These items include small snacks, various types of sweet drinks and other traditional foods. Starting with only 500,000 Rupiah of her own savings, A. was brave enough to start her own business. She had the courage to start it because her family did not have a steady flow of work. Due to her perseverance, her business continues to grow. Each week she must purchase more goods to replenish her inventory. Her business currently brings in 20,000 to 30,000 Rupiah per day. A. would now like to borrow capitol to improve the condition of her shop and offer more items to her customers so she can increase her profits.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Untuk mencukupi kebutuhan sehari –hari A. bersama keluarganya hanya mengandalkan usaha warungnya. Suaminya adalah seorang petani yang pekerjannya tidak tetap. Kalau ada yang menyuruh barulah ia bekerja sedang waktu tidak ada pekerjaan hanyalah menggarap kebun warisan dari orang tuanya. Barang-barang yang dijualnya A. seperti barang keperluan sehari-hari yang diperlukan oleh masyarakat sekitar seperti makanan ringan, aneka macam minuman ringan dan makanan tradisional lainnya. Dengan modal awal hanya Rp. 500.000.- yang diambil dari tabungannya, A. memberanikan diri untuk memulai usaha ini karena dulunya didalam keluarganya tidak memiliki usaha yang tetap. Dengan ketekunannya sehingga kini usahanya semakin berkembang. Dalam satu minggu A. harus berbelanja untuk melengkapi barang daganganya yang sudah berkurang. Keuntungan bersih yang didapat sekitar Rp. 20.000,- sampai Rp. 30.000,- setiap hari. Dan saat ini A. membutuhkan tambahan modal usaha untuk memperbaiki kondisi warungnya dan menambah kelengkapannya agar keuntungan yang didapat pun bertambah.

loans.use: to improve the condition of her shop and increase her inventory

loans.name: Khatamova

texts.en: Khatamova K. lives in Nausky, Tajikistan. She has been the client of the MicroInvest since 2003. She started her business practically from the scratch. She traded in small wares but thanks to the loans she has taken she improved the business and opened a trade outlet in the bazaar. Now Mrs.Khatamova trades in children and womens shoes. She is experienced in  business (about 10 years) and she is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work because she dreams about the good and assured future for her children.  Thanks to her politeness and sensitivity she has  repeat customers. She works with suppliers who give her the opportunity to work with the clients of  different income levels.  The prices for her goods are lower than the bazaar prices. Mrs.Khatamova requests the loan of $350 to provide  new models and to widen the existing assortment.

loans.use: to provide  new models and to widen the existing assortment

loans.name: Muyassara

texts.en:
K. Muyassara is 30 year-old loving mother of two kids. Muyassara’s husband is unemployed. Therefore she has to work very hard to support her family. For 6 years she has sold clothing for children and men in the local market. This market is very popular among the population that is why Muyassara has a lot of clients. The business brings the stable income and allows Muyassara to improve the living conditions for her family and to save money for the future of her kids.

Muyassara has been working with IMON since January 2006. She had shown herself as an accurate client having a positive credit history. Today Muyassara requests $1200.00 US Dollars to purchase clothing for men and kids to sell during the winter season. Muyassara would like to thank everybody for supporting her and to promise that she shall pay the loan in 8 months.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for men and children to sell during the winter season

loans.name: Bobokulov

texts.en: Bobokulov G. lives in Spitamen, Tajikistan. He decided to become the client of MicroInvest because all his friends and colleagues improved their business situations thanks to MicroInvest. Mr.Bobokulov became the client of MicroInvest in 2007, and now recommends herself as a reliable and highly motivated client. He is engaged in commercial service and trade. He is engaged in  cottonseed oil selling.  Bobokulov G. works with suppliers and the prices for his good is lower than the bazaar prices. He has repeat customers. But working in the trade sphere he meets the stiff competition. He wants to provide a wholesale cottonseed oil purchase to open a specialized trade outlet in oil selling. Now Mr. Bobokulov requests the loan of $650 for a wholesale cottonseed oil purchase.

loans.use: for wholesale cottonseed oil purchase.

loans.name: Sulaimanov

texts.en: Sulaimanov B. lives in Spitamen, Tajikistan. He is married and has 4 children.  He has been the client of MicroInvest since 2007.  Sulaimanov B. from the first days showed himself as the reliable client. The business stability and income increase helped him to return his previous loan. Mr. Sulaimanov B. is experienced in business (about 10 years) and has the appropriate knowledge in  livestock because he has worked with  bovine animals from his early years. He helped his father on the farm as the stock keeper and further in  livestock raising and selling and  milk production. It was the family business. Now he is the master in the railway station but he still is engaged in livestock raising and selling because he dreamed of having a large flock and to open a business in the meat products making. He has the appropriate knowledge that he has used in practice. In time he dreams of purchasing a horn pedigree bull and milk cow  for  further meat and milk goods production. Now Mr. Sulaimanov B. requests a loan of $475 for business development and the  horn pedigree bull purchase that would allow him to increase significantly the family income and permit him to plan further business development.

loans.use: for business development and a horn pedigree bull purchase

loans.name: Graca Casimiro

texts.pt:
Graca is a widow and mother of 3 children. She lives in the village of Macia, located on the 5th Barrio, and she runs her business out of one of the local markets called Quinto Congresso. Thanks to a local supplier Graca no longer has to travel to Maputo on do purchase one-day old chicklings, this constitutes savings on transportation costs. Gracas' children are all in school. With the proceeds from her business she plans on improving her home and pay for her children's education. She joined the program in 2007.

Translated from Portuguese by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Graca e vivuva e mae de 3 filhos. Ela vive na vila da Macia no Bairro 5 e tem o seu neg]ocio num dos mercados daquela villa chamado Quinto Congresso. Graca nao precisa viajar para Maputo cidade capita para comprar pintos de 1 dia , pois que localmente existe um Senhor que e o fornecedor. Assim alivia um pouco os custos de transporte. Os filhos de Graca estao a estudar. Com os lucros ela pensa melhorar a sua casa e assegurar os estudos dos seus filhos. Ela entrou para o programa em 2007.

loans.use: Graca wants to use the money to purchase vaccines and feed for her hens.

loans.name: Zamoyoni

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 51 year-old Zamoyoni A.. She is married with five children, aged between 21 and 30, and has two other dependents, who are her grandchildren. In 2000 Zamoyoni established a kiosk selling snacks and fast food. Zamoyoni has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $525 in order to purchase additional ingredients in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normA. make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her snacks and fast food kiosk in bulk.

loans.name: Boimatova

texts.en: Boimatova G. lives in Nau, Tajikistan. She is married and has 4 children.  She has been the client of MicroInvest since 2007. Mrs.Boimatova is engaged in the livestock business. It is the family business. She has the appropriate knowledge in the livestock because she worked with the bovine animals from her early years. She helped her mother on the farm in the livestock raising and sellingand the milk production . It is the only family income which is why now Mrs.Boimatova wants to try a new business. She would like to start a business in the fruits selling. Now Mrs.Boimatova requests the loan of $750 for the fruits business development.

loans.use: for the fruits business development.

loans.name: Zena's Jumuiya Group

texts.en:
Zena, age 30, is married with a 5 year old child. She has a business of selling charcoal in the Buguruni neighborhood in Dar es Salaam. It began in 2000. She works from 7am to 6pm daily, and in a month can earn a profit of about $90 from this business.

Zena hopes for a loan to increase her charcoal stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwanaidi, who sells soup for a living.

loans.use: To buy charcoal stock

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 30 year-old Alice A.. She is married with three children aged 7, 10, and 14 years. In 2005 Alice established a jewelry business and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase an additional stock of earrings, bracelets, and necklaces. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support; hence, poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase a new range of earrings, bracelets, and necklaces for her jewelry shop.

loans.name: Rose's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Rose is 38-years-old and is married with 6 children (ages 23, 19, 17, 15, 13, and 11). She and her husband also take care of her mother, who is 90 years old.

Rose is a food vendor and started this business in 2004. She works from 7am to 5pm daily, and makes a monthly profit of about $25 a month from this business. She hopes for a loan to buy additional stock to increase her business. She will share this loan with Matha, a member in her loan group. Matha sells clothes for a living.

loans.use: To buy food stock

loans.name: Thi Hanh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Hạnh, 34 years old, is married and has 4 children. All children are in school age. Family’s economy is in hardship. She has a furniture store at home. Things are tough because of lacking venture capital. She would like to borrow money to strengthen and expand her store.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Hạnh năm nay 34 tuổi, đã lập gia đình và có 4 con. Cuộc sống gia đình rất vất vả vì các con còn đang ở độ tuổi lớn và đi học. Hai anh chị mở một cửa hàng mua bán nội thất tại gia đình. Việc mở cửa hàng ban đầu rất khó khăn vì thiếu vốn, anh chị đã tìm đến tổ chức vi mô với mong muốn vay vốn để có thể mua thêm tủ, bàn, ghế... phục vụ cho hoạt động kinh doanh của mình

loans.use: Buy goods

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 35, is a single parent of 3 children (ages 20, 18, and 14). She also takes care of her mother, who is 60 years old.

Fatuma started a clothing business in 2004. She sells clothes everyday from 7am to 5pm, and now makes a monthly profit of about $45 from this business. She hopes for a loan to buy more clothing stock in order to increase her business.

Fatuma belongs to the loan group Mshikamano, which totals 40 members who keep eachother accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma, age 28, is married with 2 children (ages 8 and 3). She also takes care of her mother, age 56. Salma owns a business where she sells chips and sarongs. She started this business last year in 2007, and now makes a monthly profit of about $280. Her business is open from 1pm to 9pm daily.

Salma hopes for a loan to buy more inventory to sell. She is a member of a loan group called Ushindi, which totals 39 members who keep eachother accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy chips and sarong stock

loans.name: Thi Senh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Sênh is 56 but looks much older. She is always industrious. All her children are grown up and left home. She lives with her husband, a retired cadre. Everyday she makes and sells rice cakes, variety of kinds. She also delivers to various stands at the market. Her husband helps her. She’s never borrow money but this time she would like to apply for a loan at Binh Minh to buy material for cake making. Income from selling cakes everyday would be used to repay the loan, easily.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Bác Sênh, năm nay 58 tuổi, trông bề ngoài bác có vẻ già hơn. Bác rất chịu thương chịu khó. Mặc dù các con bác đã lớn và ra ở riêng, còn lại hai vợ chồng, bác vẫn làm bánh. Hàng ngày, bác vẫn làm bánh tẻ bán, giao cho các nơi đặt hàng. Chồng bác là cán bộ đã về hưu, thường giúp đỡ bác trong công việc làm bánh. Bác chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đâu cho đến bay giờ, bác vay vốn về mua các nguyên liệu làm bánh như: gạo, hành, mộc nhĩ... Mua nhiều một lúc sẽ được giảm giá, từ đó thu nhập của gia đình sẽ cao hơn. Bán bánh hàng ngày giúp bác tiết kiệm và trả dần một cách dễ dàng.

loans.use: Buy material for cake making

loans.name: Fatuma's Tuimarike Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 28, is married with 3 children (ages 12, 7, and 3). She owns a business of selling snacks, such as chapatis and donuts. She began this business in 2001, and now makes a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales. Everyday, she works from 7am to 6pm making the snacks and selling them.

Fatuma hopes for a loan to buy more food stock to be able to make more snacks to sell. She will share this loan with another member in her loan group, also named Fatuma. This other member is also a food vendor in her neighborhood.

loans.use: To buy more food stock to make snacks

loans.name: Thi Tinh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tình is young and industrious. She farms the family’s rice paddy, raises a bunch of egg laying hens and also tends a general stand at the village's open market. Incomes from all those activity are steady. Her husband, Mr. Trung, a village police cadre, helps her to tend her business and raises their two young children. She joins the Binh Minh to get into its financial programs for expanding her general stand. She will save and commit to the repayment schedule.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Tình là người phụ nữ trẻ tuổi, hay lam hay làm. Chị cấy lúa làm ruộng, nuôi rất nhều gà đẻ trứng, hàng ngày chị còn đi bán hàng tạp hoá tại chợ trung tâm làng, nhờ vậy thu nhập gia đình chị rất ổn định và thường xuyên. Anh Trung, chồng chị, ngoài công tác tại Ban công an xã, vẫn luôn phụ giúp vợ phát triển kinh tế gia đình và chăm sóc hai con nhỏ. Chị tham gia chương trình tài chính vi mô Binh minh để bổ sung nguồn vốn đi chợ. Việc bán hàng sẽ giúp chị tiết kiệm để hoàn trả vốn vay một cách dễ dàng.

loans.use: Buy goods

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. R. Savoeun, 36, and her husband, Mr. Sum Sorn, 43, have been married since 1988. They have four children—two sons and two daughters. All of her children are studying in a local school. Three of them have their own looms and weave at home when they have free time from their study. They learned their weaving skills from their mother. Savoeun started her silk production in 1989. She has four looms including her children’s looms for running her business. Besides silk production, she raises pigs as well. Her husband is a house constructor. Savoeun and her family live across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now she is requesting another loan for the amount of $1000. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and to buy baby pigs for raising.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and to buy baby pigs for raising.

loans.name: Irene

texts.pt:
Irene lives with the father of her 4 children. Their ages are 23, 21, 18 and 16. She lives in the village of Manjacaze, located in the district of the same name. She owns a tailoring business that offers services through special orders. She joined the credit program in 2004 as a group member but that group was dismantled and she decided to stay in the program solely. Her business has shown signs of growth: when she first started, she only had one sewing machine to work with. Now she has added a second machine and she has hired an assistant. With the loan amount, she will purchase a third machine and add a second helper to her staff because demand is expected to rise significantly once the school year starts and parents will be looking to purchase uniforms for their children. All of Irene's children are in secondary school and her dream is to be able to afford a college education for them. To accomplish this dream, which is also the whole family's dream, she will have to double her efforts. Irene's husband does not have a regular job, he makes his living by doing informal work and that is how he helps with the family's expenses. That is why she has to work extra hard so that her family does not lack anything. Irene travels once a month to purchase material in Maputo. She can get them there relatively cheaper than in Manjacaze, where she lives and does her work. She spends 340,00 Mt to travel back and forth from Maputo.

Translated from Portuguese by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

Irene e mdosta, solteira mas vive com um homem com quem tem 4 filhos de 23, 21, 18 e 16 anos de idade. Irene vive na vila de Manjacaze. Sede do distrito com o mesmo nome. Ela e proprietaria de uma alfaitaria, onde confecciona a roupa que vende sob encomenda. Ela entrou para o Programa de credito em 2004 como membro de um grupo. Mas o grupo com o tempo disfez-se e ela porque nao queria abandonar o programa optou por tomar o emprestimo individualmente. O negocio da Irene esta a desenvolver-se. Ela que quando comecou so tinha uma unica maquina que ela prorpia usava, agora ela tem amis uma maquina e ate conseguiu contratar uma trabalhadora para lhe ajudar na costura. Ela vai comprar uma terceira maquina o que o fara com o valor do emprestimo a tomar. e ira contratar o segundo trabalhador, pois que a demamda e muito grande principlmente no inico do ano em que muitos pais encomendam uniformes escolares para os seus filhos. Quando e asssim ela nao tem bracos a medir. Os filhos de Irener estao todos a estudar no ensino secundario. |O sonho de Irene e que os filhos entrem para a Universidade. Para isso ela tera que redobrar o esforco para que os filhos realizem este sonho deles e que tambem e o sonho de toda a familia. O marido de Irene nao trabalha vive de pequenos expedientes para poder sustentar sua familia, por isso ela tem de trabalhar a redobrar para que a sua familia nao passe por privacoes. Irene viaja uma vez por mes para adquirir tecidos em maputo onde sao mais baratos relativamente aos precos praticados em Manjacaze, onde ela vive e exerce a sua actividade.Para viajar a Maputo ela paga 340,00 Mts numa viagem de ida e volta de Manjacaze Maputo e vice-versa.

loans.use: Irene wants to use the money to purchase an additional sewingg machine.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mr. N. Sorn, age 36, has been married since 1972 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. One of his sons is married and lives in a separate house and the other two children are working in a garment factory in Phnom Penh. He currently works as a house constructer. He began his construction business in 1985. His wife, Mrs. Kong Yun is a housewife and grows vegetable around her house. 

Sorn is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, for $800. He will use this money to purchase a motorbike for his children traveling to work in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for traveling to work

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. P. Mao, age 50, has been married since 1987 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. One of his sons is working in a supermarket and the other works repairing air conditioners.  His daughter is working in a garment factory. He currently runs a motor taxi. His wife, Mrs. Pen An, age 39, is a housewife. Mao and his family live along National Road 2, about fifteen kilometers form Phnom Penh.

Mao is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, for $500. He will use this money to add to his own money to makes repairs to his home.

loans.use: House repairs

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S., 45, is a widow and lives with her two children and her sister in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works as a vendor selling a variety of grocery products to the people in her community, earning about $3 each day. Two of her children are lately employed by a garment factory and generally make about $80 per month each. Mrs. Ly S. hopes to use this loan to buy more grocery products to expand her business. With a larger quantity of products, she can make additional profits and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to expand her business

loans.name: Kannha

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Kannha, age 37, and her husband have been married since 1984.They have four children—three sons and one daughter. All of her children are studying in a local school and help her on the farm. Kannha and her family live on National Road 6, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is in the business of growing vegetables and rice for selling at the market in Phnom Penh. She started her business in 2000 and her husband is a construction worker.

Kannha is requesting her first loan for $400. She will use this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her vegetable growing business

loans.name: Enyonam

texts.fr:
Mrs. Enyonam A. is 35 years old, married and the mother of six children. She has to take care of the household expenses and the costs relating to sending her children to school because she is married to a polygamist who has difficulty meeting his own needs. She plans on using this loan to increase the size of her business in order to earn more and better meet the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame Enyonam A. est âgée de 35 ans, mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Les dépenses du foyer et celles relatives à la scolarisation de ses enfants reviennent à sa charge puisqu’elle est mariée à un homme polygame qui subvient difficilement à ses propres besoins. Elle pense, avec ce crédit augmenter la capacité de son commerce pour gagner plus et mieux subvenir aux besoins de la famille.

loans.use: To buy 5 bags of rice, 3 cases of milk and 5 cases of canned food

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Dina, age 25, and her husband have been married since 1999.  They have three children—two sons and one daughter. Two of her children are studying in a local school. Dina and her family are living on an island on the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been in the business of weaving silk since she was young. Her husband is a horse cart driver and does farming. 

Dina is requesting her first loan for $500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Mrs. Joy I. is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, and she runs a restaurant business and sells drinks. She is seeking for the loan of $450 to enable her buy more drinks and foodstuff. She learned this business from her friend and established it in 2002. She is a LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy more food Items & drinks to sell

loans.name: Thi Ty

texts.vi:
Ms Tỵ, 27 years old, has 2 young children. She is a young woman but very active and hard working. She has held various odd jobs to make ends meet. Today she and her husband operate a business where they would buy waste paper from people then resell to paper company. The business is quite stable and so is their family situation.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Tỵ, 27 tuổi, có 2 con nhỏ, là phụ nữ trẻ nhưng rất năng động. Chị đã làm rất nhiều nghề để phát triển kinh tế gia đình như: đi chợ, làm thuê... Hiện nay, chị là chủ cửa hàng thu mua giấy bóng. Hàng ngày, chị cùng anh Thi, chồng chị, thu mua giấy bóng của những người đi chợ. Giấy bóng thu mua được nhiều, chị đem bán lại cho các nhà máy tái chế, vì vậy thu nhập của gia đình chị khá ổn định và thường xuyên.

loans.use: Buy waste paper

loans.name: Peace

texts.en: Miss. Peace O. is 37 years old and lives in Benin City where she operates her restaurant business. She is asking for the loan of $450 to enable her by more foodstuffs and drinks. She started her trade in 2001. She has been an LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy more food to cook and sell

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr:
Mr. Kokou A. is married and has three children. Aged 33, he opened his small store almost a year ago. He wants to increase the size of his store using the profits he will make from having more stock.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur Kokou A. est marié et père de 03 enfants. Agé de 33 ans, il a ouvert sa boutique bientôt un an. Il désire augmenter la capacité de sa boutique avec les fonds qu’il bénéficiera en alimentant la boutque.

loans.use: To buy 5 bags of rice, 4 cases of milk, 5 cases of sugar and 10 cases of canned food

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. S. Man, age 25, and his wife have been married since 2002 and have one daughter. They are in the business of selling beef in a market at Kampong Cham province, about fifty kilometers away from their house. Man buys cows from his village and his wife sells the beef in the market. They started their business of selling beef at the beginning of 2007. Man and his family are living at National Road 6, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Man is requesting his second loan for $1000. He will use this loan to expand his beef selling business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Kawala 1A (I) Group

texts.en:
Jane is a 48-year-old-widow. She has a poultry farm. With the extra profits from the expanded business, she intends to pay school fees for the orphans.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more birds for a poultry business

loans.name: Adzoto

texts.fr:
Adzoto W. has been in the restaurant business for almost two years. She is 33 years old, married, and the mother of four. Her main source of income is the profits from her sales. She would like to buy 3 sacks of rice and 2 drums of oil to minimize costs in order to clear a profit. This would enable her to meet her daily needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Madame Adzoto W. opère dans la restauration depuis bientôt 02 ans. Elle est âgée de 33 ans, mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Sa principale source de revenu est les bénéfices réalisés sur ses ventes. Elle souhaite acheter 03 sacs de riz et 02 bidons d’huiles pour minimiser les charges afin de dégager un excédent lui permettant de subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens.

loans.use: To buy 3 sacks of rice and 2 drums of oil for cooking and selling

loans.name: Thi Hong

texts.vi: Chị Hồng, 27 tuổi, đã có 2 con đang học cấp I. Chị đi chợ bán hoa quả. Chị thường đi mua ở các chợ trung tâm và bán lẻ ở chợ gần nhà. Chồng chị làm mộc, chuyên đóng các đồ nội thất. Chị chưa từng tham gia vay vốn ở tổ chức chính thức nào mà chỉ vay chị em, họ hàng. Lần này, chị mạnh dạn vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô Bình Minh vì thủ tục vay mượn đơn giản, được làm ngay tại thôn không phải đi đâu xa, rất thuận tiện.

loans.use: Đi chợ bán hoa quả

loans.name: Isoken

texts.en: Mrs. Isoken O. is 36 years old and married with five children. She is the leader of her Union. She owns a salon where she makes, fixes and braids hair. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy  clothes and jewelry to sell; this, she hopes, will improve her business. She learned this business for six months and started her own business in 2000.

loans.use: To buy jewelry and clothes to sell and expand her business

loans.name: Thi Hong

texts.vi:
Ms Hồng is 27 years old. She has 2 school age children. She sells fruits and grocery items at the market near her house. She buys her fruits & grocery from a distributor and resells to make a profit. Her husband is a woodworker, he makes all kind of wood furniture. Ms Hồng has never borrowed money from a fund before, only from friends and family. This time she is determined to apply for a loan from Binh Minh cdc (SEDA) because the loan term is favorable, easy to qualify for and it's available where she lives so it is convenient.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hồng, 27 tuổi, đã có 2 con đang học cấp I. Chị đi chợ bán hoa quả. Chị thường đi mua ở các chợ trung tâm và bán lẻ ở chợ gần nhà. Chồng chị làm mộc, chuyên đóng các đồ nội thất. Chị chưa từng tham gia vay vốn ở tổ chức chính thức nào mà chỉ vay chị em, họ hàng. Lần này, chị mạnh dạn vay vốn của chương trình tài chính vi mô Bình Minh vì thủ tục vay mượn đơn giản, được làm ngay tại thôn không phải đi đâu xa, rất thuận tiện.

loans.use: Buy fruits and grocery for resales

loans.name: Kawala 1A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Cotilda is a single mother of five children. Currently she sells dry fish in the market. She wants to use the profits of the expanded business to pay school fees for the children and to buy a calf.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of fish for the market stall

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria owns a provisions store. She is 45 years old and married with 7 children. She is the leader of her union. She is from Edo State. She needs the loan of $450 to buy more provisions and drinks to sell. She has been in business since 2000.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Kawala 1A (Iii) Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 46-year-old widow with seven children. She sells charcoal to earn a living and support the family. With the profits she intends to pay school fees for the children and also buy a plot of land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
Married and the mother of four, Essi G. is 32 years old and has had her shop for almost three years now. She would like to improve her shop's capacity by acquiring 10 sacks of rice, 8 cartons of sugar, 5 cartons of milk, and 10 cartons of canned goods. Her main source of income is the profits from her sales that enable her to cover some of the costs of schooling her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Mariée et mère de 04 enfants madame Essi G. est âgée de 32 ans et détient sa boutique depuis bientôt 03 ans. Elle souhaite améliorer la capacité de sa boutique en acquérant 10 sacs de riz, 08 cartons de sucres, 05 cartons de laits et 10 cartons de boîtes de conserves. Sa principale source de revenu est les profits réalisés sur ses ventes qui lui permettent de supporter en partie les frais scolaires de ses enfants.

loans.use: To buy 10 sacks of rice, 8 cartons of sugar, 5 cartons of milk, and 10 cartons of canned goods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Sakhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Sakhorn (54), and her husband have been married since 1973. They have seven children—three sons and four daughters. Three of her daughters are married and living different houses and the youngest daughter is working in a garment factory. Two of her sons are fishermen and the other one is studying in local school. Sakhorn and her family live along National Road 5, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been running a grocery store from her home since 1980. Her husband is assisting her in doing business.

Sakhorn is requesting her second loan for $700. She will use this loan to make repairs to her house.

loans.use: For repairing house

loans.name: Kawala 1C(I) Group

texts.en:
Annet is 32 years old. She has a business selling new shoes. She would like to use the profits from her expanded business to buy a plot of land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and expand the business

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Mrs. Tina is into the sale of drinks and local gin. She is the secretary of her union. She has been in business since 2003. She is 26 years old and married with four children. She needs the loan of $375 to buy more gallons of local gin to sell. She learned the business from her mother for 8 months.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of local gin for sale

loans.name: Kawala 1 C(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Sharon is 37 years old and married with four children. She has a house with four rental rooms. She also sells firewood to supplement her income. With the extra business profits, she intends to buy a piece of land to and build more rental houses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more iron sheets and cement to expand her housing rental business

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is a LAPO member. She is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She is from Edo State .She has been in business since 2002. She needs the loan of $525 to buy more poultry birds to sell. She learned the business from her sister for 8 months and started hers in 2002.

loans.use: To buy more poultry to sell

loans.name: Yao Novinyo

texts.fr:
Yao Novinyo E., age 42, is a disabled man who is married and the father of two children, both of whom are in school. He has difficulty meeting the needs of his family since he lacks the necessary fund to finance his business despite strong customer demand. With this loan, he wishes to acquire 10 cartons of wine, 8 cartons of whiskey, and 3 cartons of gin to meet the demand and to earn more in support of his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Monsieur Yao Novinyo E. est un handicapé âgé de 42 ans marié et père de 02 enfants tous à l’école. Il subvient difficilement aux besoins de sa famille puisqu’il ne dispose pas de fonds nécessaire pour financer son activité malgré la forte demande. Il désire avec ce crédit acquérir 10 cartons de vins, 08 cartons de whisky et 03 cartons de gin pour répondre à la demande et gagner plus pour supporter sa famille.

loans.use: To buy 10 cartons of wine, 8 cartons of whiskey, and 3 cartons of gin

loans.name: Bwafuna (I) Group

texts.en:
Florence is 36 years old and a single mother of five children. She sells snacks and locally prepared dishes. She wants to use the extra business profits from this loan to open a market stall.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy firewood, charcoal, and food for her catering business

loans.name: Bwafuna (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Justine is 48 years old and a single mother of five children. She cooks and supplies snacks to a certain primary school. She will use the extra profits from this loan to pay school fees for her children.
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more baking flour, frying pans, and sugar to cook snacks for a local school

loans.name: Bwafuna (Iii) Group

texts.en:
Zalia is married with five children. She sells and distributes water to earn a living. She wants to use the extra profits from this loan to start a poultry business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase new plastic water tanks

loans.name: William

texts.en: Mr. William A. is 35 years old and married with four children; he is a resident of Edo State. He learned this business for a year. He is asking for the loan of $700 to buy more pharmaceuticals to sell. He has been in business since 2001.

loans.use: To buy more drugs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Emefa

texts.fr:
Emefa D., age 30, is married and the mother of three. She has been in this business for almost two years. She would like to improve her shop through this loan in order to help support her family with the profits from her sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer.

Madame Emefa D. est âgée de 30 ans, mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle détient ce commerce bientôt 02 ans. Elle souhaite améliorer sa boutique en accédant à ce crédit afin de participer aux charges de sa famille par les bénéfices qu’elle réalisera sur ses ventes.

loans.use: To buy 5 sacks of rice, 10 cartons of canned goods, 5 cartons of sugar, and 5 cartons of milk

loans.name: Masanafu (I) Group

texts.en:
Natasha is 34 years old and married with two children. She offers tailoring services but mainly sews school uniforms. She intends to take a tailoring course with the extra profits.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines and enhance her tailoring skills

loans.name: Blessing Chinyere

texts.en: Blessing is married with four children and is 32 years old. She sells pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and provisions. She has been a LAPO member for one year. She is an Ibo by tribe. She learned her business for 3 years and has been in the business since 1994. She asks for the loan of $275 to buy more drugs, provisions and cosmetics to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drugs, provisions and cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Masanafu (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Sylvia is a single mother of two children. She owns a retail shop. With the extra profits she intends to build rental houses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for resale in her shop

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget, who is a LAPO member, is married with 2 children. She is 32 years old and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells provisions to people living in her community. She needs the loan amount of $275 to enable her to buy more provision to sell. She has been in this trade since 2004. This is a business she learned for 4 months.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en: Jamal Z. and his wife (his wife is pictured) own and operate a hardware/home goods store in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. Jamal and his wife have raised three children here in Khachmaz and have been operating this store for the last three years. They are currently looking for funding so that they can increase and diversify their inventory stock.

loans.use: To increase and diversify their inventory stock.

loans.name: To Purchase More Foodstuffs Group

texts.en:
Jamila is married with two children. She owns a small restaurant. She will use the extra profits from this loan to pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her catering business

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 25 years old. He is married and has two small children. His elderly mother and young sister live with him in a rented house. His mother is elderly and sick.

He has a car, and he applied to borrow $1000 to purchase a new engine for it and some spare parts to fix it. He wants to use it as a taxi in order to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new engine

loans.name: Deyanet

texts.en: Deyanet K. (his father is pictured) raises sheep in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. He is a 28-year-old man and is married with two children. He has been raising sheep for the last five years and is currently looking for funding in order to increase the size of his herd.

loans.use: To increase the size of his herd.

loans.name: Muk Yemusumba D Group

texts.en:
Aidah is married with four children. She runs a poultry business and plans to use the profits to pay school fees for the children and to support the family.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To construct another poultry house for her business

loans.name: Fatuma's Muamko Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, age 40, is married with 4 children (ages 20, 18, 14, and 13). She has a business of selling clothes, which she started in 2007. She works from 7am to 5pm daily, and now makes a monthly profit of about $68.

Fatuma hopes for a loan to increase her clothing inventory. She will share this loan with Mwamini, another member of her loan group. Mwamini has a soap and ice cream business.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia is 37 years old and married with 7 children. She is from Edo State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs. She needs the loan of $225 to enable her buy more foods to sell. She has been in business since 2003. She is an LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy more foods to sell

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en: Elshad A. owns and operates a small market in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. Elshad has already successfully repaid one prior loan with Norwegian Microcredit, proving to be a customer that can be trusted. He is currently looking for funding so that he can continue to build and improve his store.

loans.use: To finish making improvements to his store

loans.name: Ntawo A (I) Group

texts.en:
Milly is 45 years old and married with three children.She has a poultry farm of laying hens. She intends to use the extra profits to begin commercial farming and to buy a plastic water tank.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To construct a brooder house for chicks

loans.name: Osagbemwonorue

texts.en: Osa has been a LAPO member for 3 years. She is into the sales of plantains, a kind of banana. She is 36 years old and married with five children She is from Edo State and needs the loan amount of $225 to buy more plantains to sell. She learned the business for 3 years.

loans.use: To buy more plantain

loans.name: Mwanaidi's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Mwanaidi, age 24, is single and takes care of her 3-year-old nephew. She has a beauty salon, which she started in 2004. She works at the salon from 8am to 7pm daily, and now makes a monthly profit of about $135.

Mwanaidi hopes for a loan to increase her services to her customers. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in vegetable, fruit, and other food sales.

loans.use: To expand services to customers

loans.name: Ntawo A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Leah is a single mother of five children. She makes and sells fruit juice and fruit salads. She plans to use the profits from this loan to open a retail shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit and a refrigerator

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is into the sales of drinks. She is 36 years old and married with three children. She is the leader of her Union. She is from Edo State. She learned this business for a year. She asks for the loan of $450 to buy more drinks to sell. She has been in business since 2002.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Ntawo A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Male is married with six children. She runs a poultry farm of laying hens. She wants to use the profits from this loan to pay school fees for the children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy chicken drinkers (water containers) and complete the construction of a poultry house

loans.name: Mariam's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Mariam, age 27, is married with a 12-year-old child. She also takes care of her 46-year-old mother who lives with them. Just last year in 2007, Mariam started a clothing sales business. From this business, she now makes a monthly profit of about $26. She works from 7am to 6pm daily.

Mariam hopes for a loan to increase her clothing stock. She will share this loan with Nasra, who is also in her loan group. Nasra has a business of selling chickens.

loans.use: To buy clothing inventory

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet O. is a tailor by profession. She is 46 years old, married with 3 children; she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been a LAPO member for 7 years. She is asking for the loan of $450 to buy more tailoring materials and clothing to sell. She trained for 4 years and has been in business since 1998.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials and clothing to sell

loans.name: Anna's Maisha Group

texts.en:
Anna, age 48, is married with 5 children (ages 31, 28, 26, 20, and 16). Her 70 year old mother also lives with her family.

Anna works daily from 7am to 3pm as a food vendor. She started this business just last year in 2007, and now makes a monthly profit of about $135 from this business. She hopes for a loan to increase her sales and will share this loan with Asha, who owns a small grocery store.

loans.use: To buy food items

loans.name: Ntawo A (Iv) Group

texts.en:
Olivia is 30 years old and married with three children. She owns a retail shop and mainly sells household items. She would use the profit from this loan to buy a piece of land.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more household products for the retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Emin

texts.en: Emin B. owns a woodworking shop in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. He is 28 years old and mainly makes tables and shelves. He is currently looking for funding so that he can purchase some new tools for his shop that will allow him to do more specialized work more efficiently.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his business

loans.name: Nosakhare

texts.en: Nosakhare O., who is a widow, has 7 children and she is 47 years old. She is from Edo State, and she is into the sales of pottery and plastic items. She needs the loan of $375 to buy more plastic items to sell. She has been in this business since 1997.

loans.use: To buy more plastic items to sell

loans.name: Ntawo A (V) Group

texts.en:
Edith is married with six children. She grows fruits and vegetables for sale. With the extra profits, she intends to pay school fees for the children.
This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: These women would like to rent more land for cultivation.

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en: Rasim M. (his employee is pictured) owns and operates two stores in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. He owns both a café and an auto parts and accessories store. Rasim is maried with three children and has already successfully repaid two prior loans with Norwegian Microcredit. He is currently looking for funding so that he can increase the amount of items that his small auto parts store has in stock.

loans.use: To increase and diversify the inventory at his auto accessories

loans.name: Vero

texts.en: Vero O. is from Delta State but her base is in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells local drinks and provisions. She is 52 years old and married with four children. She has been in business since 1977. She needs the loan of $375 to buy more drinks and provisions to sell.

loans.use: To buy more local drinks and provisions

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema, age 28, is married with 2 children (ages 8 and 3). She and her husband also take care of her 14 year old niece. They also financially support support her mother. In 2004, Neema started a tailoring business where she works from 7am to 6pm daily. In a month, she can make a profit of about $27.

Neema hopes for a loan to increase her services to her customers. She is a member of a loan group called Tujikomboe, totaling 30 members who keep each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To increase services to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna J. O. sells palm and groundnut oil. She is 46 years old, married with 3 children. She has been a LAPO member for five years, and she is asking for the loan of $275 to buy more gallons of oil to sell. She has been in the business since 1996.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil for sale

loans.name: Rehile

texts.en: Rehile I. (her employee is pictured) owns a clothing and fabric store in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. She has been working in this business for the last 10 years and is currently looking for funding so that she can increase and diversify her inventory stock.

loans.use: To increase and diversify her inventory.

loans.name: Asha's Neema Group

texts.en:
Asha, age 28, is married with a toddler. She started a business of selling clothing last year in 2007, and makes a monthly profit of about $47. She sells clothing from 8am to 3pm daily.

Asha hopes for a loan in order to buy more clothing inventory to sell. She will share this loan with her subgroup, who have businesses dealing in food and sarong sales.

loans.use: To buy clothing stock

loans.name: Buguju C (I) Group

texts.en:
Robinah is married with seven children. She has a stationery shop where she sells various office supplies. She wants to open a wholesale shop with the extra profits earned from this loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery goods for resale

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora is into the sale of clothing. She is 35 years old, married with 2 children. She has been a LAPO member for 2 years. She needs the loan amount of $275 to enable her to buy more clothing to sell. She has been in this business since 2002.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Tamilla

texts.en: Tamilla A. (her employee is pictured) runs a stand out of the baazar in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. She sells many different types of beans, grains and seeds. Tamilla has already successfully repaid two prior loans with Norwegian Microcredit, thus proving to be one of our trusted and valued customers. She is curently looking for funding so that she can increase and diversify her inventory even further.

loans.use: To increase and diversify her inventory

loans.name: Geroda

texts.en:
Geroda, age 50, is married with 7 children (ages 33, 29, 28, 25, 23, 18, and 11). Her 3 grandchildren, ages 14, 10, and 6 also live with them.

In 1995, Geroda started a fruit and vegetable stand where she sells from 7am to 6pm daily. She now makes a monthly profit of about $140 from this business. She hopes for a loan to buy more inventory for her stand.

Geroda is a member of a loan group called Imani, which totals 37 members. They ensure one another in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetable stock

loans.name: Buguju C (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Hope is 32 years old. She has a public pay phone and sells air time cards. She intends to use the extra profits earned from this loan to open a small restaurant.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a second public pay phone and purchse air time cards for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: he needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Osatohanmwen

texts.en: "The sale of kitchen utensils is a lucrative trade for me," says Mrs. Osatohanmwen A.. She is married with 8 children, and is 40 years old. She has been a LAPO member for 4 years. She is from Edo State. She needs the loan of $375 to enable her buy more kitchen utensils to sell. She has been in the business since 1999.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils

loans.name: Mushvig

texts.en: Mushvig T. is a 29-year-old taxi driver in the northeasterly Azerbaijani town of Khachmaz. He has already successfully repaid one prior loan with Norwegian Microcredit. He is now looking for funding so that he can make some much needed repairs to his taxicab.

loans.use: To make repairs/improvements to his taxicab

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Miss Esther O. is a tailor by profession. She is single, 27 years old, and she lives in Benin City. She has been a LAPO member for 2 years, and she needs the loan amount of $375 to enable her to buy more tailoring materials.  She started the business 3 years ago.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei has a successful business selling fruits and vegetables at a market in Beregovo, Ukraine. He started his business about six years ago after evaluating different business possibilities and deciding this would be the best option and something he would enjoy. Sergei purchases produce items at very low prices and is then able to resell them for a profit. Because he sells in bulk amounts, he deals with a high inventory turnover rate. Sergei rents a very good location at the market for his business and he has a small amount of competition. His profit for a typical month is around $600. 

Sergei has requested a loan of $1200 to increase his business capital. This loan will give him the ability to purchase more produce to sell, enabling him to increase his profits and continue operating a profitable business.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Buguju C (Iii) Group

texts.en:
Stella is 33 years old and divorced with three children. She sells textiles and clothings to earn a living. With the profits earned from this loan, she wants to buy a piece of land and pay school fees for the children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more textiles and cloth fabrics.

loans.name: Aisha's Imani Group

texts.en:
Aisha, age 25, is married with 2 children (ages 7 and 3). She and her husband also take care of her 60 year old father.

Aisha works as a food vendor between 7am and 6pm daily. She began this business in 1992, and now makes a monthly profit of about $65 from this business.

She and her subgroup hope for a loan to increase their businesses. Aisha's subgroup members, Zainab and Tausi, have chicken businesses.

loans.use: To buy cooking stock

loans.name: Zakia's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Zakia, age 23, is married with a 1 year old baby. She started a beauty salon just last year in 2007. She works from 7am to 6pm daily. In a month, she now makes around $75 from this business.

Zakia hopes for a loan to share with her subgroup so that they may each expand their businesses. Her subgroup members have businesses of grocery, food, and sarong sales.

loans.use: To expand her salon's services

loans.name: Buguju C (Iv) Group

texts.en:
Esther has a small retail shop. She intends to use the extra profits from this loan to pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To increase stock in the retail shop

loans.name: Salma's Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Salma, age 30, is married with 2 children (ages 10 and 4). She owns a charcoal business, which she began in 2005. She works from 8am to 6pm daily selling charcoal, and now makes a monthly profit of about $75 from her sales.

Salma hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal stock to sell. She will share this loan with Farida, a member of her loan group. Farida also sells charcoal and sells chapatis (flat bread) as well.

loans.use: To buy charcoal inventory

loans.name: Kate
